The idea of Duck Confit in a burrito didn't sound right to me.  Shouldn't Duck Confit come with Cassoulet?  French and Mexican cuisine together?  How would it taste?  Delicious.  I went because of  being highly recommended by Mish L.  Boy, was she right!  

Here's what I ordered:

Super Duck Confit & Shrimp:  A large sized burrito with a nice combination of black beans, rice, salsa, sour cream, and cheese.  The Confit and Shrimp were in every bite.  One of the best burritos in the City.  

This corner in the Potrero Hill has a great group of restaurants.  French, Italian, Japanese, and Mexican.  Papito being a must if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Michael L.

description:
A hole-in the wall find in Potrero Hill, this restaurant is great for satisfying any Mexican food cravings you might have. I've been there twice so far and both times I have been impressed. The staff there is incredibly friendly and welcoming. I have personally never had to wait for a table but have seen the lines get incredibly long. The space is very tiny so only about 5 or 6 tables fit.

Everyone gets a bowl of chips along with three sauces to dip into. On my first visit I got a carne asada super burrito--SO good. It is a bit pricey at about $10 but I was able to save half to take home for another meal. Rarely have I had a burrito where I didn't feel the need to add any extra salsa or sauces. The second time I decided to try one of their many taco selections. I got the camaron costeno taco (sautéed shrimp, garlic, avocado, mango pico de gallo) and although you only get two tacos, they are PACKED so they fill you up. Sort of difficult to eat but overall really yummy. Paired with their red sangria (probably the best I have ever had), the meal was complete. 

Next time will have to try the duck confit because they were out when we went! Although on the pricier end for Mexican food (only reason I couldn't give it 5 stars), in my books it has been worth it every time.
author: Alysha F.

description: I was visiting a friend who lives in Potrero Hill and we wanted to grab a quick bite before I headed into Bay Bridge traffic. This cute Mexican restaurant is right across the street from her apartment. It's not a huge restaurant, and seems quite popular, but we were able to grab a table immediately. I wasn't sure about the portion sizes here, I was worried that an order of tacos would just be two tiny appetizer sized tacos, but I was happy to find out that it actually makes a perfect sized meal if you're not starving. They have all different types of fillings, and what I figure out too late was that you can actually get two different tacos with each order. I ended up getting the shrimp tacos and they were tasty. This is a great neighborhood place, and if I lived closer I'd probably be here all the time.
author: caroline y.

description: My $12 super burrito better be amazing. It wasn't. Kinda bland. I've had better for $8 from taquerias.
author: Gabe F.

description: A pleasant surprise! I drove into the city early for a rehearsal and parked... Took a walk and ended up here! Don't be fooled by the small appearance. It's quite quaint and the food is delicious! A gourmet twist to a basic chicken quesadilla!!! Actually... A fried chicken quesadilla :) flavorful and every bit was worth it! Huge portions. I could only finish 1/3 of my food! The server was very personable and friendly too!
author: Francesca C.

description: Papito is amazing. The good is delicious every time I go there, the staff is friendly and polite and I always have a pleasure able experience. I order something different from the menu every time I go and it is all amazing. Yesterday I went 30 minutes before closing and they were polite and accommodating even though it was almost closing time. I recommend it to everyone!
author: Breyanna R.

description: Food was good. Server was nice and also funny which is a big deal. Even though I was crammed in the corner, my massive burrito was delicious. I'm going to take a nap now, you're welcome.
author: Jesse B.

description:
Had to update my last review: This place has to have THE BEST fried chicken burrito i've ever had. It's an interesting place - i think its fence, but serves mexican. Regardless, its usually busy because they have an AMAZING MENU.

I do have to watch my calorie intake or I'd be here everyday. Great Taco's, chicken soup and Beer! Don't tell my boss i've had a beer at lunch!

My recommendation: The burrito IS better than the fried chicken taco.
author: Heather H.

description:
Friendly staff, fast service and good reasonable prices considering the area. 
Duck tacos - excellent, moist. 
Shrimp fajita plate with black beans and Spanish rice was very fresh, hot, flavorful and filling. 
Dinner for two and two beers (5 dollars each - not too shabby). 40$ (not including tip). 

Highly recommend
author: Legal C.

description: Fajitas were really good. The mango margarita was a little too sweet though. It's a small place with Max 10 tables.
author: Anand V.

description: This place has great food but I've never been enamored by their service which kind of is a bummer. However, finally decided to order for pick up and was asked to go on hold- no big deal. But was on hold for quite a while still able to hear the person talking, taking orders, etc. not a big deal again, except it got so long it basically seemed like he forgot someone was on the line.  I guess this place is not that interested in phoned in orders for pick up?   If they charge $11-$14 for a burrito the service needs to get better. Good service with good food would go for 4 stars, ok food w ok service I'd do 3, but good food w service that just doesn't seem to care is prob 2.5, but that's not an option so a reluctant 2. :/ sorry Papito, we'll try again and if it's better do a better review. Ended up ordering goat hill instead bc their phone in service is stellar and consistent. Ops suggestion: just take the order when someone calls in, it's easy revenue and takes less than 5min.
author: Jeff W.

description: Excellent service and pleasing atmosphere....but all are second to the amazing flavors of each hand prepared dish.  The guacamole was the best I've ever had.  The tacos were Devine and the hamburger was truly a marvelous sandwich with intense flavors and texture.  Obviously, these folks know what they are doing. It's my 2nd time and they continue to impress.  Thanks for being a gem in a city full of delights.
author: Lisa P.

description:
Delicious tacos, refreshing agua frescas, friendly service... Easily one of my favorite places for a casual meal. Take-out is super easy too!

Seafood soup and mole are not to be missed!
author: J A.

description: I will not be going back. I ordered the fajitas, with no cilantro, and they arrived covered in cilantro. When I brought it to their attention they took it and brought it back and had clearly just attempted to scrape the cilantro off rather than making a new plate. Very unprofessional. The fajitas also tasted rather bland.
author: Sinclair W.

description:
I grabbed some takeout from here last night.  Got two tacos and chips and guac.  The guacamole is great, chunky pieces of tomato and they top it with cilantro and cojita cheese - delicious!!The El Pastor taco was soo tasty, I highly recommend it.  I also got the duck confit taco, which was tasty, but I preferred the el pastor.  The mango salsa is delicious, just spicy enough!!

Though I didn't sit this time, they were very pleasant on the phone, prompt when I arrived for my order, and more than happy to add all the salsas for me.  I have sat here before, and the service was good.  It is small, but cozy and cute.  

I will be back, and recommend others join!
author: Sarah F.

description:
I ordered a burrito and was surprised to find out it came with chips and three types of salsa.  Not off to a bad start. The server inside was really friendly and happy I was there.  Of course, business was booming since it was lunch time but no one was pushing me away even though there were no seats available.  I took my food to go and ended up eating at work.  

The burrito was good... not the best I've ever had but I can say it was the spiciest one I've ever had.  I mean, ridiculously, uncomfortably spicy. I guess I should expect it from a Mexican restaurant but a warning would've been nice.  I ended up throwing half of my lunch away because it was unbearable.  I can't say that my two stars is a fair rating since it's based off of the fact that I couldn't even eat my lunch so I will be going back... making sure I mention I want MILD pico de gallo.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Since 2010 this was my favorite burrito place in sf.  The supper pollo burrito with creme  fraiche was delicious and unique in sf

Tried papito today and so disappointed in the overall decline in quality,  taste and now using fried chicken vs grilled in the burrito.
author: Samir K.

description:
Very high quality ingredients but the flavors and spice are mild compared to the Mission right nearby where the food costs half the price.

Beautiful restaurant and the tables outside are great for a sunny day.
author: Matthew G.

description: We go to Papito at least once a week for either lunch or dinner. We love the place and the service. It's a simple menu with high-quality ingredients and amazing sangrias. And please stop complaining about there's no parking. This is San Francisco folks,there this plenty of parking within two blocks, learn how to walk.
author: Al G.

description:
TL; DR: Overpriced, small portions of Gringo inspired "Mexican" food. 

First, no salsa for chips. Just some red sauce. Already a bad sign of overly Americanized Mexican. 

I had the entree with pork and cod fish. The fish was fried (wasn't described as such on menu) and tasteless. I've had better fried fish at Long John Silver's (not much to be said). The pork was tasty, but dry. 

The guac was the only redeeming item.
author: Jason N.

description:
There were a few other restaurants with long lines so we settled for this place. Very Happy with that decision.

The duck confit, winner winner!

If you're hungry go with a quesadilla or burrito. Nice portion, reasonable price.

If you don't want to be stuffed, go with the two tacos, not huge, but a chance to try a variety of flavors, like, ya know, the duck confit. I'm not a fan of pickles, but the mint, pickle, chipotle mix is clean, very clean. 

The staff is very friendly. I was ear hustling a conversation down the bar and the patrons and staff were sharing family stories, it felt like a nice neighborhood coffee shop where everyone knows each other. just a good vibe overall.

The parking in the area is iffy. some days it's great, some days terrible, just don't stay too long, or you'll find a ticket on the dash.
author: Glenn M.

description: Ingredient quality has gone down hill. The beef is now super greasy and unrecognizable as meat and the shrimp smell fishy. We started going to Papito in Hayes valley where the carne asada looks and tastes like carne asada and the shrimp are large and fresh. Shame really as we love the place but not prepared to pay good money for cheap ingredients.
author: Marsh M.

description:
Came here during lunch time at around 12:30pm on a Saturday and it was fairly empty, soon after we were seated the restaurant was full. Keep in mind that this is a small restaurant with limited seating.

I was here with two other people, one person got their own dish, and my other friend and I shared another. I shared the Papito Quesadilla with my friend which was basically tempura shrimp inside a quesadilla. This dish was huge and more then enough for my friend and I to share. The quesadilla was full of the right amount of flavor.

I wanted to try the Elote, but they did not serve this during their lunch time. I will definitly be back another time during dinner to try it!
author: Dana L.

description: Been here a couple of times, the food and service are great! Jorge is usually our waiter and he is great!! Very friendly and attentive! Food is out quick and the sangria is delicioussss! Try the ceviche!
author: Alejandra S.

description: Everything i ordered was all brand new tastes to me. Make sure u order a watermelon juice to wash down your food. If your looking for something different from your normal super burrito taqueria ... Then try Papito Potrero.
author: Richard L.

description: I've had the quesadilla, burrito, and Papito combo with chicken as well as tofu - it's been great whether I'm doing take out or eat in, and the portions are big.
author: Krishna V.

description:
Tasty and organic food, relaxed and fun vibe, friendly staff. it's a great Potrero Hill standard. 

Favorites: duck tacos. 

Other great plus: organic aka non-GMO corn. This is really rare, even in our non-GMO/ pro-localavore city.

The four starts are because approximately one in three take-out orders is missing an ingredient (e.g., Papito salad not coming with avocado). Also, because there is no voicemail, or way to order if the house is busy and the host/bartender can't answer the phone.

If you're in Potrero Hill, I highly recommend eating at Papitos. If you're alone, no worries, try eating at the counter. You'll get to shoot the breeze with the host who is friendly, witty, and engaging.
author: Cecilia C.

description:
Leaving SF Sunday night and was craving mexican food. 
I am so glad that my boyfriend and I stopped here!
The braised beef super burrito was the best burrito that we've had in a long time. 
Chips and slasa being served when we were seated made my tummy happy too.
I will be making it a point to stop here the next time I am in SF because this place was in the perfect location and satisfied my taste buds. :)
author: Briana H.

description: Favorite neighborhood Mexican spot. The calamari was to die for, perfect combo with the house made sangria. Chorizo tacos and guac were delicious as well. Loved the employees and atmosphere! Can't wait to try the rest of the menu!
author: Jenni M.

description:
Executing something simple to perfection...there's nothing better!
LOVED the super burrito with chicken! Delicioso!
author: Mike V.

description: I am so so so very excited that I will be living in close proximity to this little french-mexican eatery. The couple times we've stopped by for lunch, the tacos have been deliciously inventive, and quesadillas are so satisfying, and I can't wait to try their entrees. yay for papito! the husband and i are sure to be regulars, save us a table!
author: Archana P.

description:
Papito is that odd culinary conundrum, the upscale Mexican restaurant. Odd in the fact that we all know some of the best Mexican to be had in the city is in the well-known holes-in-the-wall in the Mission like El Farolito or Taqueria Vallarta. Only one in the semi-fancy category stands out to me, Colibri near Union Square, but now I can assert that Papito is just about ready to join Colibri in the top echelon. Just a few tweaks here and there, and Papito will become a go-to place beyond Potrero Hill dwellers. I only realized it was there when Genevieve earned Review of the Day about a month ago for her familiar summary of highlights. 

I decided it was worth Jamie W. and me returning to his old neighborhood where he readily points out that Charlize Theron and Keanu Reeves canoodled in "Sweet November". Papito turns out to be around the corner from 18th on Connecticut next door to Rocketfish. It's a rinky-dink space but nicely appointed. It was a shivery evening, so we weren't much for waiting. Luckily, two seats opened up at the curve of the counter next to the window. It was a tight squeeze for the young girls at the end of the counter, but we all fit somehow. 

So I knew it was "upscale" when they didn't lay down a basket of chips automatically. No, I ordered the $6 Guacamole Papito, which afforded us fresh tortilla chips with some of the most flavorful guacamole I've had in these parts. It had cilantro, serrano peppers, queso fresco, jitomate and lime mixed with the smashed avocados (see photo). Tasty and addictive. Jamie went with the $9 Super Burrito which had duck to go with the rice, beans, fresh guacamole and pico de gallo, and creme fraiche. For all that, he characterized it as "pretty good". Mine was more of a slam dunk, the $8 pair of Carnitas de Pato Tacos, which had duck confit carnitas, homemade pickles, habanero peppers, mint, and chipotle and drizzled with tamarind sauce (see photo). Those were mouthfuls of joy bursting with flavor. 

I went overboard and ordered the $10 Carnitas Quesadilla to share (see photo). We were actually hoping they forgot it since it was late coming to the counter, and we were quickly getting stuffed. It was huge and stuffed with Berkshire pork, guajillo salsa roja, shredded Monterey Jack cheese, and a pineapple pico de gallo (see photo). Delicious though we needed to doggie-bag it. That decision allowed us in our self-justified minds to order the $5 Mexican flan, perfectly firm in texture with just the right amount of sweetness from the caramel (see photo). Definitely worth a return visit sometime soon. 

FOOD - 4 stars...solid four-star cuisine with tacos and quesadillas that soar and a burrito that was grounded for repairs 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...dark and polished but oh-so cramped 
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendly Frenchman followed by a conscientious server 
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice surprise on Potrero Hill, the forgotten dining destination...at least to me
author: Ed U.

description:
I came here for lunch after dropping off a client in the Potrero Hill housing projects. From one rugged part of Potrero to the urbane part is one way to get out of the street image.

When it comes to taquerias, I'm used to eating Mexican food in "hole in the wall" businesses. Ninety percent of the time the food is consistently pretty good. But this tiny restaurant, which is currently the top-ten hottest San Francisco business, is an upgrade from I've been used to eating. 

From the menu, I was craving for a taco. And according to many sources .i.e. Yelp, this place is best known for their gourmet tacos. I had a Carne Asada Taco and a Tempura Shrimp Taco. I get the two for $8.00. The Carne Asada is grilled and charred very nicely. Other than Japanese restaurants, not many places can make a taco with the tempura shrimp. This place gives you three big tempura shrimps in my taco. I actually enjoyed the shrimp taco. And this will be my place for a Tempura Shrimp taco. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aaDHYyIJGa5EFrFT2WAf7Q?select=RvnEgKiXvlexbsQUfmSWLQ

To complete my lunch, I also had a bottle of Pellegrino mineral water for $4.00 and chips and guacamole for $6.00. And the guacamole was green and fresh. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aaDHYyIJGa5EFrFT2WAf7Q?select=Ltea9-5rdWllmuSIgZii_Q

All items are cooked and made  with organic ingredients too. I definitely can dig that!

All the workers are very nice and helpful, including the cute lady who took my order and provide me with recommendation on the Tempura taco and other items when I return, which will be undoubtedly. 

My Visa was accepted here. 

Despite being stylish and a bit trendy, I will come back and try other organically cooked food and meal from here.
author: Matt G.

description: We got 2 super burritos (shrimp and steak; shrimp and chicken), guacamole and chips, and 2 tacos al pastor to go, and they were delicious! The burritos were huge! We'll definitely go back.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Ordered carne asada tacos, the papito salad, and some beans and rice for the kid. I wasn't really impressed with the flavor of any of it really. Tacos seemed too fancy with the wrong kind of spicy (granted I am not a lover of spicy things). The black beans were quite bland. My wife had the salad and liked it, I thought it was missing something. The margarita was good, the watermellon agua fresca was good. The service was good. We tried to order deserts but they weren't serving the ones we wanted. 

I will give it another shot in the future, but given the reviews posted here I had higher expectations.
author: K. C.

description:
Cozy, cozy, cozy... 

A very intimate sized joint that offers great service and delicious menu items. Their sangria was to die for (one of my favs!) and complimented our menu very nicely. 

On suggestion for you families out there... Don't bring the kids... It's honestly way too small for children unless they can sit at a table longer than 20 minutes. The little girls next to us (adorable...but...) had way too much energy to be at Papito. I think their backpacks and dolls sat at the table more than they did throughout their meal..

Overall, highly recommend it for a date night or small group of friends!
author: Courtney M.

description: Super yummy Mexican food up in Potrero Hill.  They make an effort to provide great quality ingredients and it comes out in the plate your are presented with.  My Al Pastor burrito was memorable, and I enjoyed the side sauces as well.  I believe one was a habanero sauce with a touch of sweetness- delicious!  Although I'm seldom in the area, and my visit was completely random, I'll make a point of coming back!
author: Andy S.

description: I love this place, the steak is uhhhh mazing.  Their sangria is also fantastic.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Rebekah C.

description:
My friends invited me out here for a quick, spontaneous dinner. Papito is the kind of small, affordable restaurant with lovingly-cooked food that every neighborhood should have.

We ordered the guacamole to share, they had the enchiladas and I got the 2 tacos for $9 deal, which the menu proudly states comes with sour cream (mmmm, sour cream). The guacamole was thick and garlicky, but missing that zest that I like in my guac. The enchilada was okay, but a little too dry for me.

The two tacos I picked were the Carne Asada (grilled skirt steak, avocado, caramelized onions, salsa molcajete, salsa roja, fresh radish) and the Papa Con Chorizo (homemade Mexican chorizo, potatoes, salsa verde and pico de gallo). 

The Carne Asada was good, flavorful, filling, yeah, yeah, blah, blah--Holy sweet mother of Jebus, the Papa Con Chorizo was INCREDIBLE!!! If God himself decided to visit the earth as a taco, I bet he would be Papito's Papa Con Chorizo. Think perfectly-seasoned meat in a perfectly-created sauce with the world's tenderest potatoes. You know how meat and potatoes is a favorite meal combination in America? Well, Papito offers a Mexican version of that and you have to try it.

The space is small, probably only big enough for a dozen or so diners at most. My friend told me the kitchen is actually run by French cooks, hence the inclusion of non-traditional menu offerings like duck confit. Not sure if that's true or just Papito being different, but our waiter (who might also have been the manager) was certainly a fun, charismatic guy who isn't averse to teasing the heck out of you in a good-natured way. Fun times, fun times.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Some things are hit or miss but one thing will remain the love of my life. Their fish burrito. Oh god I dream, drool, lust after that thing. The tortilla is slight grilled, fish moist sweet flaky white fish, lightly seasoned rice, creamy, tangy (chipotle-ish?) sauce. It's the BEST thing ever. Get it.

Carne asada torta: SKIP. Thick huge bread, dry flavorless meat.
Chicken pineapple burrito: Ok but not great. Unique but a little sweet for my taste. 

Side note: FISH BURRITO!!!!
author: Beverly T.

description: Great little Mexican restaurant in Potrero neighbourhood. Always packed, but we got a seat at the bar. The quesadillas and tacos were delicious! Perfect for a party of 2.
author: S B.

description:
It is with sadness I need to update my review, from 4 stars to 3 stars.

Why the dip?  They almost never get my burrito right.  Every time I ask for no pico de gallo, and 8 out of 10 times guess what - there's pico de gallo on it!

Dunno if it's the waiters or if it's the chefs, but they need to fix something.  All I gotta say is, carefully inspect your food if you custom order it to go.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Sadly this place has dropped from my radar.

I must admit, their fried chicken quesadilla still hits the spot but the service here makes deciding to come back a bit dreadful. I've dined in the restaurant a couple of times now (we mainly do take out since we live so close) and each time our service was very lacking. Our last time here was a few weeks ago. After being seated in the outdoor area by one of the servers, no one came back until at least 15-20 minutes later. We didn't even get water while we waited. All the while, we were seeing the servers place chips and water on EMPTY tables that were inside. Also don't care for their attitudes as well. Will probably steer clear from this place for awhile until I have enough energy to give it another chance.
author: Teese N.

description: Brought my coworkers in this cute tiniest SF restaurant. Now that my work is so close by I will be coming more often. Best Mexican food I had in a long time. Keep it up guys.
author: Mattin N.

description: Small and fancy mexican food, still very authentic. Open kitchen, restaurant looked very clean even though that it was quite cozy. Food wise, all of our meals (party of four) were outstanding. Probably the best quesadillas i had in such a place. Minus one star for the friendliness of the of the staff though, i felt somehow unwelcome.
author: Ben O.

description:
Honestly, seeing 1 star reviews of this place baffles me. Let me establish a few assumptions.

1) We are in San Francisco. Dining is not as cheap as it is in, say, my old local San Diego taco truck. We all knew this going in.

2) This is a restaurant which is serving quality food. I'm not going to expect the flavors (or price, see above) of a greasy 2am burrito. I want something a little nicer.

3) The Potrero neighborhood vibe is intimate -- small, unassuming shops which are routinely packed. This is intentional and good. The waiter is used to locals who enjoy their food, and isn't going to get in my face every 3 minutes about a drink refill. On a Friday night there might be a bit of a wait.

With that said, /wow/. What a wonderful find. I recently moved to Potrero from Palo Alto, and given the size and decor of the restaurants, I was sure I'd have to spend a small fortune on some overhyped "gourmet" portions. In other words, I'd either be frequently cooking at home or frequently guilty at how much of my budget was going to food. Papito, like Chez Maman around the corner, completely broke those preconceived notions. 

Everything I've tried has been delicious -- and this is coming from the sort of insufferable guy who always whines about [insert anything north of Los Angeles] Mexican not being up to snuff. The chips and salsa are inventive and wonderful, the calamari addictive, the burritos are uniformly excellent (try the Burrito Mojado with Al Pastor), and the duck confit tacos are out of this world. 

The people are also anything but snobby. The owner clearly loves what he does, and is very friendly. Sit at a table with a friend, or at the bar alone, and have chips and salsa handed to you almost immediately. Service is as quick and attentive as you'd like it -- I can have a leisurely conversation while dining over an hour and a half; or I can get a Corona, an appetizer, and a burrito in under 30 minutes.

Finally, by any reasonable San Francisco standards, the place is CHEAP. If you want to go all out with a beer, appetizer, and dinner, you might be looking at $20. If you just want a world-class burrito that's filling enough to hibernate for another 16 hours, you can do it for $12. No, it isn't a $4 beef-filled doorstop the size of Mark Wahlberg's arm, but is that really what you came to this neighborhood expecting? When compared to just about anything else of quality in the city, it's shockingly reasonable.

Great food, personal service, grad student prices. An amazing find, which I can only selfishly hope doesn't become as popular as it deserves to be. I'll be here every week, and I'm happy to not need a reservation.
author: Stephen M.

description:
YAY! I LOVE THIS PLACE! 

The place is small but cozy, staff is super friendly and attentive, food is bomb and always fresh. Portions are big and tasty! I found my new favorite burrito that will feed a family of 5! 

So sad I have to drive all the way over here.. but will do it in a heartbeat!
author: Jenn T.

description:
At first I thought it was the most overpriced "Mexican" food ever. Until I realized it's brilliance as a French-style Mexican restaurant. If you go beyond the usual Mexican restaurant staples, and start moving into duck confit tacos, tempura shrimp filled quesadillas, or the chorizo-filled hamberguesa, you will start to appreciate it's specialness. I believe it is owned by the same people who bring you Chez Maman, so you can expect the same great snappy French service too. :)

It's still a bit pricey, but worth it if you stick to the more unique menu items. (But not so much if you just stick to regular tacqueria/burritoria fare.)
author: Ema W.

description:
Could it get any better?! That's what I kept asking myself during lunch at Papitos.

In my usual fashion, I sampled of a bit of everything on my first visit. Every single thing was amazing. And if you need more proof, check out my photos.
- Watermelon agua fresca
- Housemade chunky guac sprinkled with queso fresco
- Elote (corn on the cob) with mayo and rubbed in spices
- Prawn quesadilla with jack cheese, mango salsa, avocado and red onion - this was heavenly...grilled perfectly and oozing with juicy, cheesy goodness. Served with a side of salsa and guac, it was enough to feed TWO.

I'm quite fond of their salsa sampler trio, especially the tamarind one. That's not something you see (taste) every day.

But it gets better. My sister accidentally dropped her fork into her lap, leaving a big salsa stain on her dress. Our server immediately ducked behind the counter and came back with an eco-friendly stain remover, which totally worked. WOW. Who does that? Papito does.

Also, they have purse hooks hidden under the bar so we didn't have to put our stuff on the floor. Score :)

I'd love to come back on a warm day and sit outside as the sounds of salsa music spill onto the street. Papito is nestled on a beautiful hill that overlooks the city and would provide a stunning backdrop to any meal. 

I am most definitely crushing on Papito. **swoon**
author: Mariela D.

description:
Mm this place was yummy, tasty and fresh! 

My friend and I ventured to dog patch to grab lunch. We checked chez maman, there was a long wait. We checked plow, there was an even longer wait. Soo we decided to try Papito out. 

First, fresh chips and 3 sauces/salsas came out and they were soo flavorful. It wasn't overly salty! I ordered the shrimp omelette. Cajun shrimp with cheese, salsa and eggs. It was goood and for $12.
author: Kayla O.

description:
We have been coming here weekly ever since it opened. Normally Olivier is quite accommodating & pleasant despite seeming overwhelmed at times as he runs the place as well as waiting on tables.

We had a mishap last week but the owner Jocelyn promptly called me and fixed it for us. i can tell that he appreciates the importance of having a loyal neighborhood following. 

My daughters and I just had the nicest and best meal there to date. the Tacos al pastor and ceviche were excellent and the Burrito Mojado tasted amazing. The guys at Papito's, from the manager to the waiter to the cooks, are all hard working, funny and very service oriented. On a warm Potrero Hill evening, seating outside is an unforgettable experience. I highly recommend it!! Merci bien. We'll be back very soon!
author: Sandra V.

description: Delicious. We had the shrimp enchilada and the pork quesadilla. And the sangria and free WIFI make it pleasurable to hang there.
author: Christina A.

description:
Very delicious.  Everything we had were good, except the one thing I specifically went for, the Mexican corn, which, was only luke warm and not even a bit charred, and just didn't compare to the super yummy ones I had in NYC at Cafe Habana. I'm hoping it was an off night though as I do love me some Mexican/Cuban corn.

I ordered the tacos (each order comes with two, I picked the al pastor and shrimp, both yummy), and we all shared a duck quesadilla.  The quesadilla was good as a share, but I don't think I can eat that whole thing by myself as an entree.  

Overall, really nice experience.
author: Cindy C.

description:
It's a bit expensive but it's worth it.
It's definitely the best Mexican food I've had in the city.
I've tried these other highly rated burrito places in the Mission and I have no idea what people are raving about.
This is the only Mexican restaurant I've been to that deserves 5 stars.
author: Javier R.

description: Definitely some of the best organic Mexican food around. Our kids love eating here too. Good service and the fried pollo tacos are a party in your mouth.
author: Emilia D.

description:
QUACK........QUACK........QUACK.......

Do you like ducks?  Do you crack up when Daffy tells Elmer it's Wabbit Season and not Duck Season?  Or when he tells Bugs, "You're dethpicable."  Well if you're like me and you like ducks, you're going to dig on Papito.  Why?  Cuz they serve up an awesome super burrito that's PACKED with dark, juicy duck meat.  That's why!

Seriously, this burrito is huge.  My eyes were like o_0 when I saw it.  Packed with duck confit carnitas-style, it's got loads of that unique duck flavor.  Like, there's no mistaking you are eating duck.  And it's juicy.  I love burritos that are juicy.  It keeps everything tasty and moist.

Papito is located up on Pot Hill.  The menu reads "organic mexican cuisine," but it has a little French twist to it (French sour cream).  If you go during the lunch rush, you may not get a seat.  The super burrito is $8 and comes with spanish rice, black beans, pico de gallo, monterey jack cheese, guacamole, and creme fraiche.  Street parking is easy breezy and they take plastic.  Shot out to Mish L and Ann S for putting this on my hit list!  Sorry Daffy, but it's totally Duck Season.
author: Joe M.

description:
We came in to grab a late lunch to go.  The server was nice, and encouraged us to sit and have water while we waited.  I always appreciate that when I'm waiting for a take out order.

We had the chicken burrito and green chicken enchiladas.  Tintin was surprised to find the chicken in the burrito was fried, but he ended up enjoying it.  All 3 of the salsas they came with were bland or sweet, so pass. The chips were good though.  The chicken in the enchiladas was not fried, thank goodness.  I am not ready for that much fusion.  

It was pricey for Mexican, but the portions were fairly large and tasty.
author: Seong P.

description: My local go-to Mexican place with delicious food and great sangria. The quesadilla is great and the steak even better. It's small though with only a handful of tables and doesn't take reservations so prepare to sit at the counter or wait.
author: Thorsten S.

description:
My wife took me here for lunch on 07AUG12.  This whole block of P-Hill has many great little eateries.  The owners of the 2 Chezs are behind it, so we arrived with high expectations and ready to eat.  The menu cover page threw us of at first because of the line, "No pesos, no tacos", but this is NOT a message to customers that it is a "cash only" place.  Just want to put that out there.  They DO take credit cards.  

The one server was running around during the busy lunch crowd, but if you arrive a few minutes before 12, you can grab one of the nice tables outside in sunny P-Hill.

We ordered the duck confit quesadilla and the fried chicken tacos for our lunch.  While we waited a small plate of chips were delivered with a 3 dish salsa selection.  Those who know me, know that I really expect great chips to support the main courses.  Their chips did not disappoint.  These were made fresh, not out of a Costco bag or generic restaurant supply house.  All 3 of the salsas were full of flavor and offered distinct directions.  I wish there was a bit more in the salsa dishes though.  

When our courses came out, we were very pleased.  Each dish was presented well and tasted even better.  The subtle combination of ingredients added that extra non-traditional flair which made these dishes stand out and memorable.  Portions were good and I could not finish my entire serving (subjective and relative here to the individual).    

This is a great modern take on Mexican food, but that they offer Mexican Jarritos soda, make their own awesome chips, etc, all again demonstrate their attention to mains as well as the details that round out a great meal.
author: Patrick M.

description: the burritos are enormo and delicious. They grill the tortillas and I'm into that right now. Guacamole is ze freshest. Tomatoes and onions on top. Crunchy and creamy. GET THE CHURROS with chocolate sauce. Enjoy the perfect combo between sips of a tecate can. Great service and it's why we drive across town for it. Gotta get here. Thanks Papito, i love you.
author: Ryan A.

description:
Cute little place we found after touring the brewery a few blocks down on a Sunday. Food was good and our waiter was very friendly. 
We ordered the guacamole to start which was a generous portion size and very well made! Also the crab cakes, which came 3 to the serving. I ordered a burrito which was about 3 times the size i was expecting it to be, giant and satisfying. My sisters equally enjoyed what they ordered though both commented the dishes were a little on the spicy side, one got the soup another the enchiladas with green sauce(which the waiter said would be less spicy than the red) I understand that is relative but just to know not for people who dont like a little extra kick. 
All in all we all left very full and happy with our lunch. We got lucky as we arrived for a late lunch, so there was space at the bar to sit comfortably but being a smaller resturant I could see it getting very full. Its a pretty darn good little mexican spot to grab a bit to eat if you're in the area.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Ew....so hungry this morning so we see this place.  It's the only café in Potrero Hill that doesn't  have a wait list to get in.  

Overpriced like you can't believe.  I order 2 tacos for $9 and ask if it comes with anything like rice and beans and the guy says "No."  

Two teeny little tacos come on a plate.  The steak (carne asada) was so undercooked when it should have been melt in your mouth for $9.  The other taco - carnitas - pork had no flavor at all.  

So sorry we tried this place.  It was horrible.
author: G G.

description:
Holy mole sauce!

After hearing the rave reviews, I figured I had to go check what all the commotion was all about. By golly... Papito's is like a burrito dream brought to life. I ordered the rock cod super burrito thinking, "Eh, I've had burritos before," and didn't really think too much about it. Let me tell you, it was probably the tastiest burrito I've had yet. The burrito consisted of your typical ingredients such as spanish rice, black beans, and pico de gallo, but what took it over the top was the slight tang of the creme fraiche and the abundant servings of guacamole and monterey jack cheese all throughout. I'm also happy to report that there were good, meaty chunks of rock cod with every bite. Since everything here is organic, I didn't feel too guilty about finishing off the humongous burrito. A little bit of gluttony, a little bit of organic. I mean really, can't they like, cancel out? 

This little gem is located in the chill neighborhood of Potrero Hill. The restaurant itself was really small and has very limited seating, but whenever there's a burst of lovely weather, there's also outdoor seating available to customers as well. They also have a small bar serving beer and wine to help wash down your gut filling meals. 

Will most definitely be back for some more!
author: Ann S.

description:
I'm a big fan of putting a unique spin on food. I've heard this is Mexican with a French spin? I think that's right. Anyways...

Lots of tasty options. They put purple cabbage on stuff and the salsas/sauces are all pretty good. Steak burritos and quesadillas are really good. So are the fried shrimp tacos.

Sangria is probably the best I've had.
author: Joe H.

description: Was amazing when it first opened, but that was years ago. Quality has declined tremendously (new ownership?) and it is not what it once was. :(
author: Poker B.

description:
We went there for a company lunch and everyone including myself loved their foods! Good comments! Their quesadilla is the best I had so far! (We are located at the mission area, and found this gem). 

Their menu price is a bit more expensive than other Mexican restaurants. My quesadilla was $11 and other places may just cost $7 or 8. But for the price paid, it is totally worthy. Their qussadilla is HUGE. By the look of their food presentation, this place seems like a little fancier Mexican restaurant, unlike Poncho Villa or alike. 

Their calamari and guac were delicious too!

The setting and atmosphere was nice. Recommended for people looking for some yummy Mexican foods. 

Would definitely go back for their quesadilla.
author: Lena H.

description: Our first meal in SF after travelling almost 24 hours from Manchester, UK. We were tired but in need of some tasty food and that's exactly what we got at Papito. My fiancée and I both had tacos. Carnitas, cachete, pastor and papito - all great, carefully made and good flavours. Prices were reasonable and the service was friendly. A pleasant experience at a charming little restaurant.
author: Edd W.

description:
The french inspired mexican food is definitely a twist. I had the duck confit quesadilla and the duck was well cooked, the sauces had just the right amount of flavor and the service was quick and painless.

It was a school night so not too crowded which I guess is probably not the norm. I also only ordered a beer so cannot comment on the cocktails. The decor has nothing special to speak to but I love that it is right around the "happening" part of potrero hill. 

I wish it were a tad cheaper but that's why the mission taquerias exist i guess. But if you are in the mood for mexican food that is different, then this is the place to go to.
author: Rahul H.

description:
So my wife and i were in the neighborhood(furniture area) and were starving so we tried maybe 3 or 4 other restaurants but they were all packed.  So enter papito, i was impressed by the high reviews and cuteness of the place, my expectations were lifted even higher when i saw the marshmallow looking michelin monster with his dumb thumbs up.  Chips were ok, salsa was not terrible but it was too bland, all 3 of them.  Guac was good but not creamy enough with too much salsa bandera, that's right, what you've always thought of pico de gallo is not really called that, i should know.
Then we got our quesadilla and enchiladas( by now you should have realized we're really into food)

Quesadilla: 
Pros: carnitas were tender

Cons: pineapple(seriously??!!!)not enough cheese, tortilla was Ubercooked, almost felt like a cracker

Enchiladas:
cons: tortilla was too soggy, too much cheese(not a quesadilla people) chorizo did not taste like chorizo, it lacked that spice.  Rice was.... well you get the idea

Pros: it was only 3 of them thank god, we don't like to waste.

I can see why people come here but it's really not for the food, prices were good, for SF at least.  But if you're in the mood for mexican better go to the mission or try some crispy tacos from this other place.
author: Roberto Z.

description:
This is s great little organic Mexican restaurant in Potrero Hill. Everything tasted very fresh and the three types of complimentary salsas was nice. The quesadillas were big and the two tacos were a good size too. The beet salad was very good. The beets were juicy and the vinaigrette was nice and citrusy. 

The food was delicious and the atmosphere was just as good. There was only five people working and they were all having a good time and doing a great job. If l lived in SF I would go here all the time!
author: Corey H.

description:
In the past year they have raised their prices 3 times. Today was the last straw when they charged me for chips(it use to be free) . The burritos are decent, however for the price of 20 including tip you my as well go somewhere else.  They really try to nickel and dime you for everything. Next week they will probably charge us for water. I have been a loyal customer for the past 2 years and I will be avoiding this place like the plague from now on. Whats even funnier is that they try to rush you out of the place when you barely sat down. For the price of a 14 dollar burrito I want to be able to enjoy it. IF you are coming by yourself you will have to sit at the bar even if there is a table available for you and within 20 minutes they will promptly try to rush you out.  
Good for people who want to spend money on little food and bad service.
author: Winston C.

description:
Went here for lunch and just had a phenomenal meal. 

We started with their complementary chips and salsa. Oh man. If they bottled this stuff and sold it, I'd have come home with multiples of each kind. The peach salsa was so unique and delicious. And I don't normally like salsa verde, but theirs is really good, as is their red, smoky salsa. The three of us polished off all of them.

I then moved on to tacos. One chorizo taco and one shrimp taco. Both of them were excessively good. The spices on the shrimp were perfect and the combination of the meats and other ingredients were just perfect. And two tacos was just enough food for a person on the smaller size -- but you can order them individually if you want more. And there is a long list of tacos with interesting meats to choose from.

We will certainly return.
author: Whitney G.

description:
Overpriced, blander mexican food.

We sat outside on a steep hill on awkwardly positioned chairs at 11:30am.  It wasn't busy but the waiter didn't get to us for like 20min.  The drink/bus boy had to keep apologizing for him.  Didn't seem like much at the time.

Our waiter finally arrived, but with an air of smugness about him.  He was short and disinterested, more interested in staring off at nothing than ever making eye contact with us.

I said, "oh that looks good, can I try one of those" pointing to an egg special being served at the table next to us.  He said, "we stop serving those at noon."  To which I replied in a jovial manner, "oh is it like 11:50 or something?."  BUT IT WAS!!!! It was only 11:50am and he said he no longer wants to take those kinds of orders.  Seriously?  I hate that little man!!!
author: Steven S.

description:
Taco's were amazing! The service on the other hand was beyond distasteful.. RUDE waitress!! this restaurant needs a well deserved training on good old CUSTOMER SERVICE PEOPLE!  When a restaurant has exceptional customer service and great food it's a guarantee that you have won that customer over. I most definitely will not be back.

Sorry Papito
author: Toni T.

description:
If you re looking for place that has great burritos and French accent waiters, trust me you ll not find anything better than papito on the west coast.

The reviewer that is complaining about the price is crazy. Compared to other places in sf this is pretty good value and yes you do get chips.
author: theo v.

description:
I've tried a lot of burritos in the city, and I think Papito has one of the best! Definitely get the Super Burrito - it has the right amount of guacamole, rice and sour cream, and plenty of flavor. Our favorites are the grilled shrimp and the carne asada. I have to give a shout out for their tacos and quesadillas as well.. both are delish. We've tried brunch once, and it was fantastic.

Their chips are always crispy. My only criticisms: 1. they used to have better salsa options (mango and green), and the one they serve now isn't nearly as good. 2. I'm not a fan of their guac when its served on its own.. I feel that it lacks lime/salt. But, it works out well in the burritos.

If you haven't tried this place yet, you absolutely should!
author: Nadine F.

description: I want to like Papito as the mexican option in my neighborhood.  It starts with the salsa which needs onion, cilantro, diced tomatoes, garlic, lime or just about anything to give it flavor instead of the tomato paste and pepper sauce that it currently is.  Moving onto the queso - its a deep dish with some cheese on top - would prefer more cheese and a shalllower vessel.  The guac was ok and I really appreciate a refereshing michelada to wash everything down.  I've had a couple of varieties or tacos and they've been ok, just nothing as tasty as Gracias Madre, Cha Cha Cha, or Tacolicious in the Misison.
author: Brian G.

description:
On a rainy Sunday morning after spending some time playing with my little love bug my husband and I wanted to grab some Mexican food to satisfy our hunger. 

I suggested Papito since I've been wanting to check it out and it was super close to my son's play place.  I scored a parking spot close to the restaurant and was supper happy because we didn't have to walk very far in the rain.  

We were greeted immediately and since it was super early there was no one in the restaurant yet and we got to choose a bigger table for our family of 3.  :) 

We told the waiter that it was our first time at the restaurant and he made a few suggestions.  I wished I ordered their Watermelon drink but I was in a blah mood because of the rain so I opted for the water and ordered the shrimp quesidilla while my husband settled for a burrito.  We also ordered guacamole to spice up our chips!  The chips also came with 3 differnt types of dips and they were all great. 

The food was great! 

Service was wonderful as well and parking wasn't too bad! 

Glad I was able to check it out and will definitely be back to try it out again.
author: Christine P.

description:
4 stars for the DUCK QUESADILLA.

AMBIANCE: tiny spot crammed full of THINGS (diners, the bar, the kitchen, staff...).  It was quite hot inside despite being a typically crisp/cool SF evening outside.  We identified the major source of heat being the exposed bulbs hanging overhead.  Weird.

SERVICE: friendly and prone to bantering. 

FOOD: I split an order of super burrito with duck and carnitas de pato quesadilla with MM.

- Super burrito + duck ($8, +$2.50): disappointing.  Maybe the burrito was rolled so that the fillings weren't evenly distributed, but my half had one small strip of duck and was mostly rice & beans.  There was absolutely no duck flavor... actually, there wasn't much flavor to the filling at all.  If I were to rate Papito on the burrito alone, they would've received 2stars.  PL & AD also shared a duck burrito (and a fried chicken burrito), and found it to be "too sweet" (I can't confirm, since my burrito was uber bland).  They preferred the fried chicken burrito.

- Quesadilla + duck ($12): SO GOOD.  A fairly large quesadilla stuffed FULL of shredded duck meat, with a smattering of pickled carrots/daikon, refreshing mint, and a sweet tamarind sauce.  I really enjoyed the flavors in this dish-- perfect harmony of savory and sweet.

OVERALL: It is clear dishes at Papito are composed of fresh ingredients.  I just wish they took more care in ensuring every bite has the flavor profile they are aiming for.  I think prices are fair for the food they're offering... IF all items are composed like that duck quesadilla MM and I shared.  I'd be happy to return and try other items on the menu.
author: Susanna W.

description:
The Hawaiiano taco and Pozole were 2 of the most mind-blowing things I ate throughout my entire California road trip. Not only is the food exceptional, but it's moderately priced, great service, and comes with free chips and salsa (which is spicy and awesome and everything nice). 

5 stars highly recommend. peace~
author: Nate M.

description: This place is a mexican french fusion focusing more on the mexican side. Service is very good. Waiter explained the menu and was very accommodating. I ordered the rustic shrimp enchiladas which were very flavorful. My mom ordered the duck tacos. Those were delish as well. We also had the guacamole. The best guac Ive had in a long time.  It was fresh with cojita cheese on top. Definitely going back.
author: Shana W.

description:
Please note:  I don't give out 5 stars freely.  Some of my other reviews are given 1 star because service and food quality go a long way with me.   To get 5 stars, I have to be very impressed!

My first visit to this place was 8/25/13.   Right off the get go, I found some of their menu items are not common for  Mexican food restaurant (duck, fried chicken, battered and fried cod).    The place is small yet cozy.  The music is not my normal choice but seemed to fit the crowd (hipster type music).  The guy who waited on us...  What a great guy to have representing this restaurant.   He was very confident in the food from this restaurant and that right there set the bar high for my expectations.

The salsa's offered were delicious.   Salsa verde, a chipotle red salsa with a little heat, and a mango salsa (in the form of a sauce however).    The drink selection is ok fare, good choice of Mexican beers (Corona to Pacifico), house made sangria, and champagne mimosas (also offered in other flavors such as raspberry or mango).

My girlfriend ordered a mushroom quesadilla and I ordered a chicken burrito.    

The unique feature to their chicken is that it's not the standard stewed chicken you'd find in most taquerias.   It's a fried chicken.  I am not sure but I believe the only beans you can get is black beans, which are very delicious and way better than re-fried or pinto.   The burrito meshed well together.  Normally I am not a fan of Pico de Gallo on my burritos because it can run the flavor of everything else.   Tomatoes have a lot of citric acid in them and can ruin a flavor just as much as Mustard can, but I digress.....   instead of Sour Cream they use Creme Fraiche for the creamy part.   Overall the burrito was well constructed and tasted delicious from start to finish!   I dabbed a little Salsa Verde on it as well but really you wouldn't have to because the burrito was great!

The mushroom quesadilla was delicious and a good choice for veggie folks.   Granted this dish is NOT vegan but it helps give choices to the many Veggie folks living here in SF.    Savory cheese with the earthy pungent taste of mushrooms!   Quite delicious.   The quesadilla itself was cooked very well.  Not like what you'd get at Chilis or Chevy's.   Very hand crafted and made with a lot of care and respect.  Not burned.   The size of the quesadilla was amazing as well!

So I have to note:  My girlfriend had a raspberry mimosa, and a bug landed in it.   The guy behind the bar gave her a brand new drink when all she asked for was a spoon to get the bug out.  Much appreciated.

I also noticed that this guy was good with the hand washing after petting someone's dog outside the restaurant.   As soon as he walked back in, the hands were washed.  Having someone be dog friendly but then respect the  humans paying to eat here (and subsequently be the lifeblood of any business) speaks in volume!

I also observed other gestures by the staff that go beyond what they really should do and it made me feel like I was eating in someone's home.   Very comfortable setting!

I'd say my only gripe about this place is the parking.   But hey, it's SF, we should know better than to expect royalty parking ;-)

We will be back because I am intrigued by the duck!
author: Craig T.

description:
Nice location with a cool view of the city. Very small venue so it can get tight inside and out. Great service. And the food was great. 

Had the super burrito with fried chicken, definitely a first but was great. I will definitely be back next time I'm in the area.
author: Ahmed K.

description: Great creative and fresh dishes at reasonable prices. Cool staff and bright fun interior make it a good addition to Potrero.
author: Tom O.

description: I'm not a Mexican food fan due to the calories, but this place defies Mexican food stereotypes of being heavy and mass produced. Everything is organic and fresh and just fantastic. Will be back while I'm here.
author: Debbie S.

description:
The trio of salsa to add on your food was great to have. Although I didn't care much for one of them, I was constantly pouring on the other two to my veggie burrito for flavor. And the complimentary chips that accompanied my meal.

Besides one other patron we were about the only ones in here so service was attentive. They made sure we were provided filled glasses of water which is great because Mexican food makes me very thirsty. 

Prices are pretty spot on. Although I can pay less for an "authentic" burrito this place offered fresh, organic, clean tasting food that wasn't oily, or too heavy. Parking was easy as there are plenty of spaces a bit higher up on the incline.

I have my favorite taquerias here in the city when I get a craving for Mexican (which is often). But Papito offers up a version of Mexican food with a touch of their French inspiration which is not something you see everyday. Apparently their duck confit tacos are awesome. I can't vouch for that since I'm not a meat eater and I've never had but the positive reference of this dish seems be a recurring trend within Papito's reviews.

They offered a terrific selection of desserts which I was too full for. Indeed, I will be back to try them.
author: Esther A.

description: The service is amazing.  Anything with the fried chicken will be delicious.  I got the Sopa Ranchero, and it was really tasty too!
author: Sam Y.

description:
Mexican served by a sassy Frenchman? Sure, I'll bite. 

Solid, tasty choices. I prefer a bit more lime/garlic bite in my guac, but still fresh and good. Our entrées were so large we both wound up taking some home. 

Tiny little restaurant with as many tables shoved in as possible, so it's a little... intimate.  You basically can't get out without moving the table aside to make way. We were there late, so the place wasn't full. The noise level was manageable, but I think if the place was packed, it would have been a little hard to handle.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
First time here; I wouldn't go back of my own accord.

We had brunch, and I ordered a breakfast burrito listed on the menu to have veggies like chilies, corn, and mushroom, and goat cheese. I asked to add al pastor pork.

I cut off a piece of it when it arrived, and didn't taste any pork or goat cheese. I started to pull out the burrito filling, looking for either ingredient: none.

I really didn't eat much of the burrito, and when my boyfriend was done eating his huevos rancheros, the waiter tried to hand me a to-go box, which I turned down. He asked again if I wanted the box, because he could see I didn't eat much of my burrito. I told him, no thanks, and btw there wasn't pork in it.

He responded, "Are you sure?" and then instead of apologizing or offering me something to replace it, he just said, "Well I put it into the computer..." and said "I won't charge you for the pork." Gee, thanks...

Just one of those things; I thought the waiter was pretty unhelpful and I just didn't care anymore. I wouldn't go back here because of the service and the mistakes.
author: Katherine R.

description: Papito is a good neighborhood restaurant nice for dining in or picking up from.  Most of the food is great, but expensive compared to a taqueria ($14 for a steak super burrito).  With that being said it's all supposedly organic and the ingredients are high quality.  The portions are also big.  Minus one star because one time I ordered a margarita and it was terrible.
author: george c.

description:
YOU HAVE TO have the Elote Asada - grilled white corn thickly slathered with Mexican mayo, homemade chili salt, lime, and queso cotija. The grilled corn is sweet, juicy, firm, and slightly browned. The Mexican mayo, cheese, and lime are creamy and tangy. The chili salt that comes on the side adds intense spicy saltiness and made this hunk of creamy corn (speared on a fork for easier eating) even more amazing. Maybe I went a little crazy with it on my second piece of corn. No regrets at all.

Also got the Carnitas De Pato taco - duck confit carnitas, homemade pickles, mint, chipotle tamarind sauce. Couldn't really taste the duck confit, it was just mostly the flavor of carnitas. They pile on the meat on these tacos but it was overall pretty bland. Next time I'd ask for it without the chopped mint on top because it was pretty strong.

The Ceviche Papito with lime marinated shrimp was decent but not amazing...it was pico de gallo, with 4 large shrimp and a few chopped up bits of mango. It comes with chips (in addition to the complimentary chip basket that they give you with three different salsas).

Lastly we had the Tostadas Trios - one with duck confit carnitas, one with slow cooked berkshire pork, one with sauteed shrimp? They are really tiny, so I only got one bite of each. The duck confit carnitas and slow cooked berkshire pork tasted very similar (porky).

The ingredients are fresh and organic, and our server was very engaged. I want to come back to try the quesadillas...they looked really good, especially the one with  sauteed wild mushrooms, huitlacoche garlic, epazote, guajillo pepper, and oaxacan cheese...the enchiladas...and more of that delicious ELOTE ASADA.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I've been on a wild goose chase for awhile now for a great vegetarian breakfast burrito in SF. The bar is set high because I was spoiled with Chill Out Cafe back home in Santa Cruz.  Added to my strife is the awkward fact that I actually ACTIVELY hate eggs, which are technically the ingredient that makes a breakfast burrito breakfast. I like to sub with tofu, but not everyone has it. 

I was pleasantly surprised to see breakfast burritos on the menu here at Papito so I ordered and... Score! Was able to sub with tofu. The other ingredients were tart goat cheese, pablano peppers, corn, tomatoes, black beans & mushrooms. Pretty swanky for breakfast. Maybe that explains why they're $10 a pop, but I'll take it.
author: Amber K.

description:
Came for a double date with my cousin and her beau. They unfortunately did not receive a big shipment of food they had been expecting so we had a more limited menu to choose from. But at least you know that they only use fresh ingredients!  

The space is small and intimate and a great spot for a double date since it was so quiet inside. 

We ordered the:

- Carnitas de Pato $12 (duck confit carnitas, homemade pickles, mint, chipotle tamarind sauce) which was very heavy but very delicious

- Enchilada Rojas with chicken $15 (coloradito sauce, crème fraiche, chihuahua cheese, black beans, spanish rice) which was my second fave item of the night. 

- Enmolada $15 (braised chicken, oaxacan mole, crème fraiche, monterey jack cheese, black beans, spanish rice, pickled red onion) - GREAT mole sauce

- Hambergersa $11 (beef chorizo, caramelized onions, avocado, queso fresco, spanish fries, chipotle aioli) which was ok, but really cheap

- Churros, chocolate sauce $7 - fresh and so good, but a little greasy.

I heartily enjoyed the whole evening and definitely recommend this spot. :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Fresh ingredients...so yummy.  You don't feel like you have grease coming out your pores when you're done. Papito is the Mesican frère (hermano if you prefer) to Chez Mama right around the corner.

It's definitely a little pricier than a tacqueria in the mission but I also don't feel like Papito can be compared to that. They have duck and fried chicken tacos. When you order a steak burrito, you actually get steak and not chunks of fatty ground up meat.  When you order shrimp, you actually get large shrimp, not those tiny bay ones.

The tacos are yummy but kind of on the expensive side -$9 for two little street tacos.  The super burrito is large and awesome - around $12 depending on your choice of meat.  The quesadillas are also really delicioso.

If you don't want to wait for a table, grab something to go...it tastes just as good.
author: Becca L.

description: Delicious beef tacos with some sort of sauce that really highlighted the meat and cut what can sometimes seem too heavy with beef.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Stumbled upon this nice little Mexican spot for lunch today.  Ordered the guacamole which was good but pricey.  Also had the chicken quesadilla which was very good but too huge to finish.  I especially enjoyed the red cabbage they add to the quesadillas.  Nice touch.  Service was excellent.  The bartender/server was very friendly, made good recommendations, was attentive and even sent me home with some extra chips for my leftover guacamole.  5 star service.
author: Reena P.

description:
Taqueria afficianados, put aside your cynicism; an organic Mexican bistro run by French food gurus sounds contradictory, no doubt, but take one bite & there's no denying their offerings are delicious beyond reproach.

The bf & I had an early dinner here on Friday (what a way to start off the weekend!) The minimally decorated restaurant (save for pairs of sombreros & mirrors) seats a dozen at the tables, six at the bar & another six outside. 

From beginning (watermelon agua fresca $2.25, elote $5, guac & chips $7) to end (Mexican chocolate soufflé with creme anglaise & whipped cream $7), each plate pleased our palates with kicked-up flavors. 

Tacos ($4.50 each) were served on double corn tortillas & topped with generous amounts of crema. I chose shrimp: one tempura (best I've ever had) & a spicy one called 'camaron costeno' (the avocado & mango salsa were superb compliments to the sauteed shrimp.) The bf had one carne asada & one al pastor & said that although they weren't outstanding like the rest of our meal, they were good enough to make him want to try other menu items (i.e. duck confit tacos.) 

I'm completely taken with Papito.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Sooo good! Came here for an early dinner on a weekday, and the place was already half full. I got a normal al pastor burrito, while my friend got the super burrito with steak. Both were delicious, and huge! Service was insanely quick. A little on the pricey side, but hey, it's San Francisco.
author: Jen L.

description: Great food and perfect location in Potrero hill.  Don't miss this small and intimate gem while in SF.  One of then best burritos in the bay.
author: Chad R.

description:
4 solid stars for this modern type flair 

I think this was mexican french cuisine, it was interesting 

I sampled this place for lunch with a fellow coworker we sampled 3 things off their menu

we got to sample there Hamburgesa - meshed meats of beef and chorizo, decent meats make for a decent burger, juicy almost a bit to juicy for there bread holding together the burger, I would try it again if I were to come back

the duck confit taco- this was excellent on so many levels, duck relatively fatty meat with sort of a spicy sauce can't put finger on what it was, mint was actually in this taco as well, the duck again was not dry, not to oily, tender and mix of hot and freshness from the mint was excellent, definitely a must try.

Baja taco - thought of wahoo's fish taco didn't think it was gonna be any good, to my surprise their version was better then I expected I would order it again

food **** duck confit all the way, definitely must come back for more
price $$
service **** 
ambiance **** small restaurant, good for lunch and for small groups (less then 4)
author: Clarence A.

description:
Cute little restaurant in Potrero Hill. There's a bar area where you can sit on stools, or dine at a table (inside or outside). Seems like this place gets a little busy since there's a waitlist sign outside of the restaurant.

I went here for dessert: churros con chocolate, to go. The order came with 4 churros and chocolate sauce for dipping, AND a bag of chips and 3 types of salsa. Perfect! The churros were delicious with the right amount of cinnamon, and the chocolate sauce was yummy. I didn't eat my dessert immediately after it was ready, so I wonder if the chocolate sauce was warm/served warm because that would make it even more delicious. The only thing keeping me from giving this place 5 stars is that my order was $7. Pretty pricey for dessert, especially for this kind of desert, but after all, Papito's is in Potrero Hill... can I give them this pass? Eh... Nope! Wouldn't come back just because today's trip was spur of the moment. Good job though! You made me happy!
author: MARTHINA C.

description:
Honestly, what is there not to love about Paptios! First, it's in the most charming neighborhood in SF with an amazing view. Second, the staff is always super friendly and the owner is funny and bubbly as hell. The food delicious, fresh, relatively healthy (?)...well it certainly isn't greasy like you typical mission taqueria. It's a little more refined than that with it's duck burrito and all. Best of all is that it is inexpensive!

Easily pay $10 each for a massive burritos and all you can eat fresh chips and salsa!
author: Sonya S.

description:
I've been here a few times over the years, and it's another adorable spot on Potrero! 

A little more expensive than typical Mexican fare, but it's not typical Mexican fare. Wonderful dishes done just right with EXCELLENT service :)
author: Susan W.

description: great vibe. they have oysters in a Mexican restaurant so we tried. ALL of them are fresh&clean! we also tried all 10 tacos on the menu. EACH OF THEM ARE SO WORTH TRYING! personally i love duck confit & veggie the most!
author: Yujie Y.

description:
Still love Papito! I brought some coworkers here for lunch today. There were five of us and we wanted to sit outside. Some other customers were nice enough to switch tables so that we could fit two together. 

As usual the food was delicious and the staff was friendly and served us pretty quickly. Everybody raved about how delicious their meals were and it was nice to be able to sit outside and enjoy the nice weather.
author: Casey S.

description:
Second impressions.

Wasn't impressed with my first visit below.

Very impressed with brunch at their newest Hayes Valley location: http://www.yelp.com/biz/papito-west-san-francisco-3?hrid=MkHoc7z2rmA5tP7eA59fbg

Figured it was time to give the original another shot even though there was hesitation paying $12 for a torta and $7 for churros. Except:

- Torta was huge. Enough white meat shredded chicken, homemade guacamole and caramelized onions (cheese and aioli are standard too) on ciabatta for two meals. 

Except it was so good it was finished in one. Including the side salad.

- Churros were triplets. And while they could have used a bit more sugar they did come with chocolate dipping sauce.

Dipping solves all. Just one reason why  this second impression earns four stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
Came here friday night for a fabulous dinner of enchiladas rojas and margaritas.  We really enjoyed the ambience of Potrero Hill, which isn't our typical stomping ground. But we had so much fun walking the hilly streets to the restaurant from a nearby dance studio.  Papito is about at 20 min drive from SFO.  There were a lot of peeps in their 20s and 30s enjoying the night and having dinner here and at the many restaurants nearby.

Papito was a tiny little place, with both outdoor and indoor seating.  We signed in and the wait was just a few minutes.  The server was super sweet and attentive, very happy and really made the dinner all the more enjoyable.  Although it got crowded, and tables are close together, with the other customers laughing and talking, it was easy to have a conversation.  We had such a fabulous, fabulous time, the food was AMAZING.  And that is not just the margaritas talking!  Or the free tequila shots our server gave us at the end of the meal!  It really was delicious.  I would definitely recommend Papito!  Five stars all the way!
author: A. H.

description: After two years of visiting at least twice a month, I can honestly say this place is among those I miss most having left SF. Papito has everything you could desire when craving Mexican and when I'm not dreaming about the Fried Chicken Quesdilla I remember how phenomenal the Chefs and host staff is. Everything is phenomenal and if you want something special or extra spicy just let them know. It is a must and is always my first visit when back in town.
author: Valerie B.

description:
Really good fresh mexican food!  The duck taco is a must and I will look forward to the other tacos!  We had the fried chicken - yummy!  We had the pozole and I think about going back just for that all the time when it is cold.

They will allow you to mix and match the tacos so take advantage of it!
author: Amy C.

description:
Loved the tacos and the quesadillas here. 
Fresh, flavorful and organic. 

Both vegetarian and non vegetarian food was amazing. You do get chips. You can split the tacos ( 2 tacos to an order and you can order two different kinds). Loved it. 

The place is small so not really suitable for large groups.
author: Rutuja K.

description: I'll say this, the flavors are here. But its so over priced. I guess fusion means charge more for no reason. Burittos start out at 8$ then you still have to add meat for a minimum of 2.5$ baiiiiiiii. This is one of those places I can only visit near payday.
author: Naimah M.

description:
I had dinner at Papito on Sunday night, my friends and I were amazed by the service and the food. The French waiter was incredible attentive and helpful by giving us great recommendations. 
The food was so good, full of flavors, felt fresh and healthy, the burrito mojado was out of this world, so huge and delicious 
Good food, amazing service, great music and very reasonable prices 
We ll definitely go back!!! 
thank you Papito!
author: Tony T.

description:
If ever you are faced with laminated menus permanently trapped under glass tabletops, DINER BEWARE. Fresh, local, and sustainable THIS PLACE IS NOT. 

But it isn't the bland salsas and store-bought generic tortilla chips that position this in the Places To Avoid category. It is the inappropriately RUDE and HOSTILE staff that really sets this place apart from a typical San Francisco taqueria. 

Apparently this place is owned by the same French group that have bought up the neighborhood: Chez Maman, Chez Papa, Chez Blah Blah Blah, you get the idea. Folks who live in this neighborhood refer to them as the French Mafia, and their import of French rudeness is very unwelcome and necessary. 

We have NEVER been in a restaurant where the staff so clearly would rather you leave. 

The place is tiny, so of course the "server" (tattoos, heavy French? accent) chose to shout at us from across the empty room rather than actually approach the table. Keep in mind, this was 2pm on a Sunday, prime brunch time and yet the tiny restaurant was completely empty except for one table. 

When we tried to order queso to start we were told tersely that it would take "a long time" and that we "should order guacamole." Then we were told we should "order everything at once so the cooks would know what they needed to do." WTF? Seriously? Maybe if we didn't have to play shuffleboard with the water glasses and bland salsas, we'd be able to read the menu. The guy just stood there and glared at us, daring us to ask another question. He did not even offer us drinks. 

Eventually we felt so uncomfortable that we decided to leave. We asked, from across the room of course, if he had placed the order for queso. His response was: "Yes, I told you it would take a long time." No thanks. We immediately told him to cancel the order and stood to leave. The rude "server" disappeared into the kitchen without a word.

Don't believe all of the fake 5-star reviews of this place. Avoid this and ALL of their restaurants: Chez Maman, Chez Papa, Chez whatever.

RUDE, RUDE, RUDE!
author: J D.

description: We were in Potrero Hill so figured we would stop and try Papito since we have been to the one at Hayes and loved it.  I was sadly mistaken that the food would be the same.  We ordered the fajitas and they were covered in a red sauce and we were given miniature wraps to make our own fajitas.  The wraps were so small you couldn't get anything in them.  Very disappointed with the fajitas as well.  They were marinating in that sauce and tasted terrible.  I would recommend Hayes Papito but not this location.
author: Danielle R.

description:
Organic Mexican food by French people? Oui et c'est formidable. 

This is a go to spot for me on those nights when I want a quick bite outside of the little Hermitage where I work and live. Papito offers bar seating in addition to tables and I've had some interesting, conversations with friendly fellow diners as well as the French guys who run the place. It has a cosy, friendly vibe that's popular with Potrero and Dogpatch folks. Papito has character AND characters.

The food is always delicious and hey, it's organic Mexican. That's gotta be healthy, no? I'm a big fan of the grilled shrimp burrito. Somehow it's both light and filling. 

Bottom line: Papito gives a delightful French twist on Mexican. A great choice for solo dining on Potrero.
author: Lauren C.

description: The location of this restaurant is nice, tucked away in Potrero Hill.  The place doesn't offer much in the way of vegetarian much less vegan options (cheese, cheese everywhere, even on the salads).  Dishes are a little on the bland side as well.  Also, the restaurant is quite small ( I'd say a party of 4 max as there is no table space) so get there early or make reservations.  The atmosphere wasn't great, lots of workers going in and out carrying vats of this and that ( I think the kitchen may be shared with the restaurant next door).  I also found the French waiter to be a bit arrogant.  I will not return.
author: Cassandra S.

description:
Papito is enchanting.

A small organic Mexican restaurant, nestled in the Potrero Hill.

Trying to warm up at the Indie Mart -  from this Sunday's down-pour, I decided to take advantage of the clearing sky, and explore the area - and venture over to Papito.

As the sun began to peek out from the emerging puffy white clouds, I spied the welcoming store-front of Papito. Upon entering I was greeted by enthusiastic charming wait-staff - who quickly made sure I had a seat, a big glass of ice-water, and a menu in front of me.

I ordered a veggie burrito with avocado and mushrooms to go.

While waiting for my order, I scanned Papito's menu quickly. Their selection is impressive. All of their cuisine is organic and their dishes are inventive and unique. With a slew of dishes - that breathe life into fresh vegetables and wondrous meat dishes - through seasonings, marinades, and sauces - I wished that I had more time and people to share the wealth of flavorful dishes, that Christina C - alludes to - in her review - http://www.yelp.com/biz/papito-san-francisco#hrid:i5-tfkNvreALsjeI-N_2Xw.
