I thank my lucky stars that I found this place, and I can't wait to eat again....
author: Christine R.

description:
Awesome food, service, and ambiance!

Went for lunch and ordered a super duck burrito. Duck was good quality not fatty and of course this burrito had all the fixins like quac, sour cream. They also serve some house salsas. They were all good but the tomatillo was my favorite. It added just enough spicy to my burro.
Staff was friendly and attentive. I like how they take the extra time to pour your soda for you even if it was super busy.
Ambiance reminds me of little busy bistro which felt like a little euro get-away for lunch! 
All in all perfectiòn!
author: Maurice A.

description:
I've been here twice now, and WOW, these guys are awesome.

+: Rock cod burrito: burrito w/ crispy fried fish = DELICIOUS and good even, the next day. I ordered the same thing as my first visit, just to make sure my taste buds were working right the first time. And yes, still delicious. Get it "regular" or "super", it doesn't matter, the rock cod is fried fresh and the crispiness shines through the burrito.
+: portions are huge, enough to even share, or save for later
+: service is surprisingly amazing. My roommate and I ordered an appetizer and wanted to save some of it for my meal. After 20-30 minutes, we were sitting there w/ a half eaten appetizer wondering if they have forgotten about our entrees.. then it totally hit us, the waiter was waiting for us to finish our app, and never once rushed us - this is why I say it's surprisingly amazing! When we realized this, we finished our app, and our burritos came shortly after - crispy and hot.
+: chips are addicting, and their trio of salsas are tasty
+: duck taco was pretty tasty

-: ceviche is nothing to write home about... 

It's quaint, but it's not a bad thing. Never a long wait, and always a friendly face as you walk through the entrance.
author: Tammy T.

description: Interesting to be greeted by a French waiter at a Mexican restaurant. Nonetheless, the food was good and the setting is nice. I'd consider it gourmet Mexican. Go early if you have kids as space is limited.
author: Jason W.

description: pepe le pew meets speedy gonzales to create papito...sunday, eight:thirty pm arrival...full and wait listed...popular mexican with french influences...short wait and seated...small and cozy establishment...2010 vionta albarino, rias baixas spain $thirty-four to start...little over three times the market price...similar to a pinot grigio with slight more tang...standard fresh guacamole $nine and mexican street corn $six....one corn conveniently cut to three...salty, cheese powder and spice kick good...a duck confit burrito $nine gushing tender duck with fresh beans and rice....crispy browned tortilla wrap...sweetness of the duck coming through strong...a sweet and savory burrito experience...quite different and new experience...tacos small and dandy....duck and pork tacos $four.fifty each...would recommend the quesadilla $twelve to be the best bang-for-buck...sampling a tender el pastor filled quesadilla...cut to large and fat wedges...quite the filling feast...served with fresh guacamole and salsa...bubbling cheese and meat center....crispy tortilla toasty...guzzling a second bottle of wine...complimentary sweet and easy la quinta agave wine to finish...24% alcohol....luscious wine meal at $fifty per person total....$one-hundred-fifty meal and wine for three diners...
author: Hen A.

description: This cute little neighborhood place has awesome grub, awesome sangria, and an awesome staff! I live no where near the place, but it's one that I travel across town just to eat at! Veggie and Shrimp tacos are my favorites, when I still have enough room  for them after munching on their chips.
author: Sasha M.

description:
This cute little spot has a fair amount of seating inside and out (be prepared to get cozy with your neighbor inside) and the service is pretty awesome. I went with 4 friends on a Thursday night and the host/server/owner(?) was super friendly and accommodating considering a couple of us were late. 

You can mix and match the tacos so I tried the carne asada and duck tacos. OMG. The duck tacos were AMAZING. Just the right amount of tender, flavorful duck and the pickles on top provided just the right amount of acidity. I'm drooling just thinking about them! 

I will definitely be visiting this place again and might sample the duck quesadilla. mmmm...

note - they only serve beer and wine so the margarita is made with agave wine.
author: Karena Q.

description:
Papito has jumped to the top of my lunch spot lists.  Upon sitting down, you are quickly served with chips and 3 different types of salsas.  The French influenced Mexican mix just works.

The duck and baja tacos are good.  However, the quesadillas are what I love most.  You should try the crispy chicken quesadilla.  The chicken is fried to a light crisp and is topped off with cabbage, guacamole, and salsa.
author: Danny P.

description:
Nestled in the restaurant heavy intersection of 18th and Connecticut, with establishments like Aperto, Chez Papa, and Chez Maman, is Papito, a cozy little mexican restaurant (owned by French guys) located on Connecticut street.

Papito is my go to place when I don't feel like preparing anything at home and want something I know is good and I know is fast. It never disappoints.

I never stray from the following:

Guacamole to start
Fried Chicken Quesadilla to finish off the meal

Mmmm mmm good!!!

The service staff and owners/managers make this place easy to come back to as well.
author: Cheryl S.

description:
New favorite place to grab a quick, delicious dinner! It's comfortable, inexpensive, and the food is wonderful. Plus, if you sit at the bar, Paolo will attentively supply you with drinks, information, and introductions.

My husband and I went to Papito tonight (7:15 on a Saturday) and there was a very short wait. We sat at the bar and got tangled in conversation with a few regulars and the bartender (Paolo). It was so comfortable. We had the guacamole (delicious - and I'm picky), sopa ranchera, and beet salad. All yummy. We also tried the bajatacos (fried cod) and the tacos al pastor. Mmm... And finished with the molten chocolate cake (with espresso cream), which came highly recommended. So good.

Only complaint is that the sopa ranchera was a bit oversalted, but the ingredients and flavors were good and it could've been a meal in itself. Of course, I couldn't skip a taco...
author: Lindsey P.

description:
If you want mexican food this isnt really the spot. But if you want mexican / french fusion than wallah!

The prices are high for mexican food but they do offer something other than the norm like the duck confit. 

I dont think of wine and tacos going together but they have it here(also expensive).
author: Joseph M.

description: Loved this place when we lived in San Francisco. We went here at least once a week. They have great white sangria. The tacos are a little over priced but it was good.
author: Karina P.

description:
I've have only eaten burritos here.  I personally like it with duck confit because it is one of those meats that you can really distinguish.  I also like the grilled shirmp and chicken.  I thought steak was mediocre (too salty).

 A little pricey for a burrito  ($10-12) but it is pretty good and is quite large.

Also comes with chips and 3 different types of salsa.
author: Steven F.

description: Small Warmly Colored Space + Great Glass of White Sangria with Bits of Apple + Creative and Delicious Duck Confit Carnitas Taco + Interesting Fried Chicken Taco + Flavorful Trio of Sauces (Green Tomatillo, Yellow Mango, Red Smoky Hot Chili) + Fantastic Churros y Chocolate + A Complimentary Tequila Shot from a Charming Frenchman = ORGANIC MEXICAN FUSION AWESOMENESS
author: Amy C.

description: The food is great, especially the duck tacos.  The outdoor seating is lovely for lunch!!
author: Mary M.

description:
Ay!
I may need to move in next door.

This bright little taqueria is Chez-Maman sized, with a similarly small but diversely tempting menu.  The chips with the trio of homemade salsas kicks the meal into gourmet-style from the start.

Just one thing - may I caution against "quesadilla style"?  The quesadillas and the tacos are excellent.   The tacos quesadilla style are just trying to do too much.  Don't be greedy.

Simple, organic, a little Euro, quiet innovations and sparks of flavor.  At the top of my list for tacos.
author: Jennifer B.

description: I've tried every restaurant in this corner of Potrero Hill and this is the hands down winner. The tacos are fabulous. The sangria, which at most places I usually find overwhelmingly tastes of cheap wine, was SO good I ordered it two nights in a row, along with my tacos. It's a teeny-tiny place but I haven't had to wait thus far. And oh the churros, the churros. So many delicious churros.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Came to san fran to visit we went here for dinner hands down the best burrito i ever had the pork chop special is awesom the shrimp tacos are out of this world  great service mexican cokes how can you go wrong fairly priced great food and people i will be back before i head back home for sure thanks
author: Lynne A.

description:
Potrero Hill rarely disappoints, and this was no exception. After living in San Diego for 13 years, I'm fairly picky about organic Mexican food. This place did not disappoint. 

Chips were perfectly made, 3 interesting salsas (red, green, and mango), and that was just the beginning. 

I had the carne asada quesadilla, which was enough food for 3 meals (literally, I'm having the third piece right now). Very tasty with good quality meat and cheese, avocado, cabbage, and some interesting special sauce that somehow made the whole thing juicier. 

They have a good wine selection, too. 

Not a lot of seating, though, and the entire time I swear the woman standing outside was glaring at me because she wanted our table (rude!), but assuming I don't have to endure the angry glares of hungry strangers every time I visit, I would definitely go back.
author: Sam Z.

description:
I heart Papito's for their fancy French Mexican food.  Yes, it's $9 for two but they serve DUCK CONFIT tacos here.  Yes, you heard that right.

I sometimes don't want to tell people how much I love Papito's because it's still relatively easy to eat here without a reservation.  This is probably why it took me more than a year to write a review for this place even though it's already been a staple in my diet for over a year.

Onto my loves (in order of how frequently I order and thus love them):
5 hearts: Duck confit taco
5 hearts: Homemade guacamole
4 hearts: Enmolada
4 hearts: Pastor taco
3 hearts: Camaron costeno taco
3 hearts: Diabilito (will be upgraded to 5 stars once I order it more often!)

Just go already!
author: Jean A.

description:
It's a couple bucks more expensive than your average taqueria, but it's well worth it.  They use top quality ingredients and several dishes have an interesting French twist, due to their being owned by the Potrero French Mafia (also owning Chez Maman and Chez Papa).  The burritos are outstanding and have unique salsa and flavorings depending on the meat.  I'm a big fan of the duck confit and fried chicken burritos.  The only meat I don't really like is their Chorizo, which is oily as hell.  If you are hung over or sick I recommend the Posole, which is only served on weekends. Their vegetarian options are plentiful, and unlike most taquerias, their veggie burritos are filled with an assortment of well-cooked and seasoned vegetables- much more interesting than the standard regular burrito minus the meat.  

Its a tiny space with a small, busy staff, so calling in orders ahead can be challenging. Overall, a great alternative to the mission!
author: Paul T.

description:
This place far surpasses waiting for the 45 minutes - 1.5 hours @ any other brunchy place.  Papito always seems convenient with no wait and wonderful service.  The food has been great here every time I've tried it out.  I usually try not to OD on mexican, especially to start a day... but they have enough options to keep me satisfied.  

They also have great cappuccinos and sangrias!  Ey ey ey!
author: Stephanie F.

description: I stumble upon this place by accident. The food is delicious service is excellent and friendly. The duck tacos lives up to the hype keep up the good cooking and I will return soon Cheers
author: SAMAY A.

description:
Food is good, but a little pricey. 
Service was a little slow.
Empty decor and a little cramped. Either do bar seating or be a group of no more than four. 

Had two tacos: papa con chorizo and carne asada. And the chicken enchilada. Devoured the enchilada. Tacos were good too, but was stuffed from the enchiladas. Would definitely eat at Papito again if in the neighborhood already. 
Also, if you're impatient to wait, the neighborhood has quite a few restaurants there that are worth trying.
author: B M.

description: Very small spot but don't let that fool you. I had the steak burrito and it was amazing, especially the meat. Next time I'll be having the fried chicken burrito (sounds interesting). Great service and would recommend it to anymore.
author: Shaf R.

description:
After a day of trekking around the city, and being ignored at the sushi restaurant down the street (on a thursday, with no one in their outdoor seating area) for a solid twenty minutes, i yelped and found papito. We were about to go to a show at bottom of the hill and all needed some sustenance, so we walked the extra block and a half to papito.

I'm not gonna lie, when i looked at the menu, I was pretty skeptical of the 4 star rating. Duck confit, in a burrito? Fried chicken? This place looked weird. 

so we sat down to eat. i got the burrito with the red sauce (I forget the name!) and grilled shrimp, and my wife ordered the hamburgesa. Also something I normally wouldnt do at a mexican restaurant - order a hamburger. 

The burrito was one of the best burritos i've ever had. not what you'd expect from a taqueria or local mexican joint, but super fresh, delicious ingredients. the red sauce really MADE the burrito. 

Also? the hamburguesa, meat with chorizo and a fried egg on top? amazing. I had two bites of it and would actually go back and order that if i wasn't in the mood for a burrito. (lets be honest, that will never happen.)

The service was amazing. I'll def be eating here every time i go to bottom of the hill.
author: Alexys P.

description:
This is the restaurant I'm going to miss most when we move out of our neighborhood. 

I had been eating here for a while and never even considered the burrito mojado because I had these memories of white-trash "wet burritos" from the Middle West where I grew up. Fortunately I was food-stalking someone one day, saw the burrito mojado that they make at this place, and that changed my mind. Fried chicken burrito mojado with their chile colorado sauce. It's two meals worth of food, if you exercise a little restraint on the first pass. It's amazing. I'm going to have to come back to this neighborhood just to get one from time to time.
author: Daniel H.

description:
Pretty yummy!

So...first things first: the Bread used for the Torta and Hamburger is awesome. Like better than awesome! Oh yeah!

The queso fundido is more like Nacho topping than it is melted cheese. We really liked it, but it isn't cheese dip.

The guac is very good. That said, it is basic. Some shrimps, fried jalapeño or bacon would make it perfect.

The duck carnitas are very good. They were nice enough to make a Torta with it and it was really yummy. The meat was a tad dry but the sammich had a good bit of saucy flavor to it.

I would definitely come back and try more things, but I probably wouldn't get the guac or the queso again. They were very good...but nothing spectacular.
author: H B.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood, Papito!

We'd been eying this spot for months, praying for a yummy, quick little lunch joint, and as it turns out, our wishes were granted. Conjured up by the Chez Maman and Papa crew, they've cemented their Pot Hill stronghold by adding yet another eatery to their list. As a regular at their other establishments it came as no surprise that the food was a party in the mouth.

Add an "ito" to anything Mexican, and it's a safe bet it's going to be adorable. Case in point, Papito is bright, modern and intimate without the Jesus candle and fake flower touch. It's menu is as Mexican as the French team could get, offering tacos, burritos and quesedillas made with fresh, organic ingredients and accompanied with festive salsas.

To those who rant about how "over-priced" and "unreasonable" it is, I implore you to order the carnitas de pato (duck) and baja (rock cod) tacos. With impeccably cooked, generous helpings of meat, I'd be hard pressed to find another place where you can get that quality and portion for $4 each. Once you shed your ideas about Mexican being uber-cheap and sink into the awesome yummmm experience, I have no doubt you'll be won over by Papito.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
They are doing take out now! Favorite item: super chicken burrito!!!!

Watermelon fresca! We split the chicken burrito super (no guac) carnitas, chicken + steak tacos, + ceviche. Divine!!

Josh the manager is so kind and attentive. So happy to have a lovely addition to Potrero Hill!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Papito is one place in Potrero Hill you don't want to miss.  Their food is some of the most flavorful Mexican food you will ever have.  The owners are French so there is a little bit of a French flare to the food, but its 90% Mexican.  I love the chips and salsa  too. I could eat them endlessly. Organic ingredients.  Reasonable prices.  Guacamole is the best I've had.  My favorite dishes are the Carnitas Quesadilla and the Fried Chicken Quesadilla.  Easy parking too. 

The customer service here is stellar.  Paolo and Olivier will take excellent care of you.  Those guys are as friendly as they come.

Highly recommend!
author: Ash S.

description: Ordinary at best, really, which is quite unfortunate. I found it rather bland and lackluster. If you want Latin/Mex, go somewhere in The Mission.
author: Maria C.

description:
Just got turned on to this place by a couple friends and it is amazing!!! Best mexican I have come across in the city so far ... its fresh, unique, and just oh so flavorful ....  quesadillas are great, tacos, ceviche, dips, grilled corn, and sauces I love it all and will definitely be back to check out more of the menu ... 

the staff is extremely attentive and friendly ... its a small restaurant as well with a little bit of out door seating so there might be a little wait ...

All in all price is reasonable but the food is well worth it .. delicious ... Pretty much as good as it gets ...
author: Anthony S.

description:
A super burrito for $10 may be ok for this neighborhood but it is still too pricey for me.

I wanted to get a taste of the duck confit and carne asada first, so I ordered their 2 tacos for $8.

The ingredients were nice and fresh and the trio of sauces were also pretty good but the meat and tortilla was a little bland. I did like the duck more than the carne asada.

Papito fills a void at Potrero...but the Mission is about 5-10 mins away.
author: Sam T.

description:
Papito offers delicious, classy & artfully presented organic mexican fare in a fun and intimate space on Potrero Hill. No suprise that this place is a winner, seeing how it's part of the Chez Papa family of restaurants, but this time they went for Mexican instead of French. Definitely a good choice - they pull it off well. 

I got the chance to sample quite a few things off the menu, including the elote (grilled corn on the cobb w/spices & cheese), heirloom tomato & nopales (cactus) salad, shrimp ceviche, classic fish tacos, guacamole and cantaloupe agua fresca! I am a big-time fish taco connoisseur, and this one definitely made the grade, done simply with beer battered fish, purple cabbage and chipotle mayo on VERY fresh & soft corn tortillas. The agua fresca was also remarkable, as was the elote. Everything was good. 

The statuesque french waitress was also very helpful in giving recommendations and great service! This is a small operation run by people who truly care and it shows. I would not hesitate to give them my business any time!
author: Shannon R.

description:
in response to the last review from the "dog walker".

i have been eating at papitos since their opening and have never had anything but a great experience food wise and service wise.

i live in the area and know all the staff including the kitchen guys and there is just no way that this incident happened.

staff are all great genuine guys. olivier, angel, grandi, roland, marco! all great folks!

read all this guys reviews: all one star and really over the top negative.

guys needs to stop slandering peoples businesses.


probably some weak minded unsuccessful cretin who envys anybody who is doing well.


keep walking your dog..........mental retard.
author: SIMON R.

description: My favorite burrito place in the city. I'm sure purists will point to the dozens of taquerias lining mission but that misses the point. This place is clean, uses organic and super fresh ingredients and the service is friendly and super fast. I would give it 6 stars but have to bring it down a bit for the unimaginative beer choices.
author: Manish K.

description:
Delicious. Duck confit tacos were terrific - carne asada extremely flavorful - nice with cabbage and a slice or two of avocado. Delicious guacamole. It's not the most "authentic Mexican" but I could care less. Tamarind (I think?) salsa was good. Duck wasn't gristly, carne asada wasn't fatty or greasy. All ingredients tasted fresh.

Service was a bit inconsistent and the place is small but got there early enough to get a table for 4. We each ordered two tacos but one ordered a quesadilla as well which for whatever reason took awhile despite the place not being too busy. These moments I can over look however since the food was so good.

I'd definitely recommend this place and hit it up for a return visit. A solid 4/5.
author: Ross R.

description:
I decided to give this place a second chance today with a coworker and got called out on my 2 star review by someone who works there!  (Manager, maybe?)  He came over to me and said 'I hope you like your meal this time, last time you didn't like it. I read your review.'  He was very sweet about it, but I could feel my face turning red and  wanted to hide behind the salsa trio.  Which, by the way I enjoyed much more today-I even liked the sweet one (mango maybe?)
The enchiladas were very good as well, I especially liked the cabbage salad.  Our server was attentive and charming.  I'm glad I gave you a second chance Papito, sorry for the 2 star review (I must have been having a bad day.)  And to the cute French guy who called me out 'You taught me a lesson today, and that is to steer clear if I write a bad review!!'  But I'm glad I didn't in this case.
author: anne m.

description:
was in SF this past weekend for work and had a hankering for a delicious burrito.
went to Papito for my fix.
GOT IT! 
super carne asada burrito extra spicy.
ABSOLUTELY delicious
author: Elliott G.

description:
Me and my hubby always get take out from here when we're lazy to make dinner and feel like lighter-style mexican food.  Papito was really really good when they first opened.  Everything was just perfect, but slowly as they got more popular I have to admit we have gotten some food that was just eh.  If I had reviewed them in the beginning, I would have definitely given them 5 stars.  The prices have gone up too...but, with the economy and all...

However, with that being said, I still think their burritos are pretty damn tasty and satisfying. The guacamole is damn expensive for what it is, but it is so tasty.  I always get a burrito or tacos, usually veggie or fish.  My hubby always gets the carne asada burrito and it's very good.  We have gotten salads and the corn there before, but were underwhelmed. So now we just stick to burritos and tacos mainly.  

The place is really small and is always crowded, so definitely a great place to get take out from.
author: Sharon T.

description:
This place is a lovely little corner restaurant that uses fresh ingredients to serve fancied-up Mexican food.  The prices reflect that, but it works. 

Their a la carte tacos seem to be very popular.  I liked the shrimp one and felt the duck confit one was too fatty - but good by most standards.  I really liked their ceviche appetizer and am wishign I tried their Ensalada Papito.  I'll be back!
author: Irene K.

description:
LOVED Papito.

I visited the restaurant today for lunch and the food was impeccable. On first visit, my friend and I shared the following,

an order of two duck tacos, CARNITAS DE PATO
grilled corn on the cob, dusted with cheese  and chile powder, ELOTE ASADO
mushroom quesadilla, QUESADILLA de CHAMPINONES
and an order of three churros with chocolate sauce

Served with three salsas each dish was substantial without feeling greasy; the dishes were all flavorful and fresh. The quesadilla included huitlacoche which is an amazing ingredient if you've not tried it yet. Combined with the mushrooms a standout umami experience. The duck taco was tangy, juicy and bright, contrasting nicely with the fresh, crisp salad it is dressed with. The grilling of the corn brought out a lovely, round sweetness which compliments the savory of the cheese and the tang of the lime and chile very well. And you just have to get the churros for dessert. They must be made to order as they came out piping hot, with a delicate, crispy outside edge which breaks to reveal an airy-light , soft center.

Papito occupies a lovely, sunny spot in a neighborhood you'll want to allow time to explore. The service was attentive and super friendly; I enjoyed the fact that the staff has a french accent. Fun! I thanked them by saying 'merci', and that was playfully returned as a, "...gracias" and  then an "au revoir" which was quickly replaced with an "Adios" . . . pause . . .  and finally a "see you later!" --and I will!
author: Mark N.

description:
I'm not sure I'm quite ready to pay $9 for two street style tacos, no matter what's inside. But I must admit, the tacos were pretty decent.

I had the duck confit and fried chicken tacos. The duck confit was made carnitas style, and I have to give it up to them. I probably would've mistaken this for pork had I not known. The fried chicken on the other hand was a little dry though.

I'm of the opinion that Mexican food is supposed to be for "la gente." When you try to spruce it up, it loses a little of the pizazz that makes Mexican cuisine so unique and delectable. It's not any different here... While I appreciate their dedication to organic ingredients and their different combinations, I think it lacks the soul that real down to earth Mexican food has. 

Their menu is quite interesting and I would be motivated to come by and try their other offerings. But it might take me a little while to get over the price.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Really INTERESTING.....that its the French man's take on Mexican....Healthy Mexican!! 

Got dinner "To Go" on a rainy Friday night and managed to avoid the full house they had. Got a chicken burrito, grilled corn-on-the-cobb, heirloom tomato and cactus salad..... and some steak tacos. Definitely mind-expansive......liked the salad and the fried onions on top (but could have lived without the cactus). The salsa's were tasty and creative, food tasted fresh and the hubby liked it.....so was a hit in my book! They were very nice and took care of me right away when I walked in to pick up the food!
author: Lee M.

description: Good god this place is good. Carne Asada torta and guacamole and chips, red sangria. To die for.
author: Chris M.

description:
Best French Mexican in San Francisco without a doubt. Their food is phenomenal. They use only the best ingredients and it makes a big difference. The staff are extremely professional and friendly.
This is one of my favourite restaurants in San Francisco, hands down :-)
author: Conor L.

description: Organic mexican food at its best. Stopped in for take-out tacos during lunch. They have a number of tacos you can chose from so I got the tofu and grilled shrimp. They were both super delicious and ready quickly. Would love to come back to try more stuff.
author: Anna V.

description:
As far as this restaurant goes, the best thing about it is the food.  And given that food is pretty important in the restaurant business, that's a big plus.  I thought their quesadilla with mole sauce was amazing.  A bit sweet, a bit tangy.  Delicious!

I wouldn't call them "Mexican," though.  Mexican-inspired, but with a fusion/French twist.  

The second-best thing about this restaurant is fast, friendly service.  The staff seem to be genuinely glad you're there and happy for your business.  I can't even say how much good service means to me.

A few small downsides: 1) portions are pretty small.  2) prices are not accordingly small.  3) the restaurant itself is REALLY small.  

No, I'm serious.  (3) is actually a big problem.  As I sat in their restaurant and tried to use my knife, my elbow was basically in the face of the guy at the next table.  And there wasn't a polite way for me to rearrange without breaking my arm.  I just had to apologize and try to cut my food as little as possible.

So my advice is order take-out or eat there when the sidewalk tables are out.  Be prepared for some very good food, but at a price.
author: Mike G.

description: For starters I have to admit I was really hoping this was gonna be my "go-to" Mexican food place since it is only two blocks from my house. The bottom line is I was was gravely disappointed. The guac was a "watery" consistency and not spicy at all. Actually none of the food had that traditional Mexican kick you look for in a good Mexican place. Everything was pretty bland. It was more a french-mexican fusion restaurant than actual Mexican. A lot of the foods had fruit in them and personally I don't like "sweet" Mexican food. On top of that, the tables are pretty much on TOP of each other so you can't really enjoy a conversation with someone because you know the table next to you can hear everything you are saying. SKIP THIS PLACE.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Back to the bitch board.

Had the duck confit burrito tonight. Tasted just like pork. They are getting more and more stingy with the pico de gallo. Took 20 minutes to get my order (which in all fairness they did mention over the phone when I placed my order.)

..& that's a wrap.
author: Reena R.

description:
Papito pops out of nowhere - it's small (less than 20 seats inside with another 6 or 8 outside for those willing to brave the chilly SF evening). 

 The kitchen seems to sit right above your head, which is great - you get to see what's going on.

The food is organic and fresh.  They mainly have burritos, quesadillas and tacos, but with multiple options of each.  There's definitely something for everyone - the vegetarian, the pescatarian and the carnivore (ie me).  

The salsa is great, but the portions are meager and they charge you for each refill.  The guac is tasty as well.

I opted for a margarita and a carne asada quesadilla.

My margarita was definitely not the best I've had, but also not the worst. I ordered a margarita on the rocks, salted rim.  I got exactly what I asked for, but rather than enjoying the contrasting dance of sweet and tangy drink with the salt, I got a salty drink with a salty rim.  It was the first time I'd had a "salty" salted margarita.

The food was pretty good and for the most part the serving sizes are large (the tacos being the exception).  My quesadilla could have easily fed two and in a sense it did...me that evening and my friend the next day.  The enchiladas come four to a plate and unfortunately you cannot mix and match your order - it's either all pork or all chicken.

And yes, the rumors are true - your meal ends with a shot of tequila, brand unknown.  A different and fun way to end a meal.
author: Rupi C.

description:
we came here for a late lunch/brunch and it was good!

when we sat down chips and salsa were brought right away.  i got a watermelon agua fresca and it was yummy.  also ice tea which they kept refilling.

for mains we had the shrimp enchiladas with chile verde and then the crab benedict.  both were really delicious!  service was attentive and fast
author: claudia y.

description: I normally don't take the time to leave a yelp review but this place deserves it. I had the duck confit and el pastor tacos. It is an excellent restaurant  - not cheap - but definitely worth it. Don't let the so-so looking exterior deter you. Would definitely recommend.
author: Sergey L.

description:
I can honestly say that when I was living in Potrero Hill, I ate at Papito at least once a week and it was always, consistently, delicious. 

The service is also pretty amazing and once they get to know you, their recommendations are off the chart. They are always speedy, attentive and lively. 

Sadly, I no longer live walking distance from Papito. However, it is well worth the trek across the city. Their tempura shrimp tacos are the best!
author: Megan V.

description:
The food is good to great but I've been 4 times and the food and service has been inconsistent. The people who run it are just plain rude. 

Out of four visits...
-We've been over charged twice on already pricey food.

-Once they didn't get our order right

-Once we ordered over the phone without a menu in front of us. We asked to add cheese and guac to a burrito instead of suggesting we order a super ($1 more) without the creme fraiche, they charged us $1.5 for each additional item. 

-Once on the way in to pick up a take out order the manager was smoking in the doorway and flicked his cigarette in my path then blew smoke in my face as he led me in to get my order. 

It's owned by the same folks who own chez maman and chez papa,  it's french mex.  So why the tacky vernacular sign, especially for those prices.
author: Heather M.

description: The only "organic" thing here is the freakin' measly tortillas.  All the other ingredients are cheap Sysco supplied staples.  I've dug through their trash looking for empty champagne bottles for brewing beer and got a look at what they use.  Sad and false advertising here.
author: Carl H.

description: Papito is good, but sometimes overpriced. The tacos are $9 for two, and quality-wise they're probably worth it. But to me that misses the point of tacos. Tacos are supposed to be relatively cheap, but also delicious and filling.  That said, the staff is always incredibly friendly and fun to talk to, service is good, and the burritos are great too. I've been here a few times, and I can guarantee I'll be back for more.
author: Chris M.

description: Great burrito. Fried chicken burrito. Need I say more? Sauces were good too. Highly recommended.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Like most, I had high hopes for a Mexican place on Potrero instead of having to drive an extra 10 minutes to Pancho Villa.  Just had lunch and, well, I guess I'm going to keep driving.

As others mentioned, it's more of an upscale Mexican/French-ish affair, but the execution is pretty weak.  IMHO, if you're going to upscale a cuisine, do it well before you try to integrate other cuisines.

I ordered the duck confit quesadilla ($11). I visualized as a gooey thing broken up with bits of crispy duck leg.  I ended up with a decent-size flour tortilla filled with a bit of cheese, dry duck leg (with zero crispy skin), a ridiculous amount of pickled and waaaay too sweet jicama/carrots.  By the third bite, I was bored with it and the weirdly flavored (some herbs) pickled vegetables overwhelmed what was there.  Maybe that much would make sense in a fatty Banh Mi, but not in a dry quesadilla.  On the side were a ramekin of pico de gallo and guacamole that didn't help anything and (this irritates me) the guacamole was of the type that is made way ahead of time, doused in a huge amount of lime juice so it doesn't oxidize, and ends up tasting like sour green paste.  If you're charging $11 for a quesadilla (and $10 for a burrito), spend the 30 seconds to have guacamole somewhat fresh.

Other person had a burrito filled with same pickled vegetables and tortilla chips that tasted like Tostitos (they weren't, but they had that coarse yellow corn taste).

Sodas are $3.  C'mon.  Lunch for 2 with tip: $36.

I was going to give it three stars because it wasn't really bad per se and the portions were fine, but then I thought: would I ever come back here again?  The answer is sadly no (but I'll continue to go to Chez Maman/Papa and Pizza Nostra, so you'll still get my $$$!).
author: Michael B.

description: I love the creative and delicious menu here! The service is fast and friendly.
author: Diana G.

description: I only go here because Angel is the best!! Every time I call for takeout they tell me they are too busy or hang up rudely after saying "we are too busy call back!" The food is good but quality has decreased lately- burnt fish in my fish taco and soup not as delicious as usual. So sad bc I love Angel and the proximity to my house.
author: Jazmin L.

description:
I'm not going to sugar coat it, nor am I going to overly embellish the negative.


Here are the facts:

* Hot night out, decided to eat outside in the hood. Sitting outside was nice. (Jackass cars who pull right up to the curb to perpendicular park with their headlights on and engines running notwithstanding.)

* Hot night out, had to ask FOUR different staff for water after about 15 minutes finally got some. And there were nearly as many wait-staff as tables, so...

* Ordered dinner, and did my best to pronounce the 4 tacos as they were in the menu. Waitress repeats (in uninterested french accent) after each item I pronounced ... "Duck" ..."Chicken" ... "Shrimp" ..."Fish".
If you're going to go through the trouble to lovingly name and describe your items on the menu, don't degrade the experience by repeating what I said like some pissed off short order waitress in a diner.

* Sangria was dry. That's fine. But it was really dry. Not refreshing or sweet enough. Tasted like wine where someone had accidentally dropped a piece of fruit in it.

* Another wait staff came by and asked us (we did not ask) if we wanted more chips. We said yes, cheerily, never to see him again.

* 4 tacos came. Pretty tasty. Nothing extraordinary, but we enjoyed them. The "Duck" tasted a bit more like overstewed pot roast, though. Listen, Duck is a delicate thing. It can be gross more often than not. If you're going to make it, treat it with some respect. Serve it delicately. 

* Check came. The price is solid, though. 4 tacos, 2 sangrias. 30 bucks. Can't complain too much.... or can I?


*...Midnight. My girlfriend complains of a bit of an upset tummy.


* 5 am. I wake up feeling weird. I head to the bathroom. I'll spare the details beyond stating that it came out of both ends with a force unlike I've ever experienced. (Ever.)



Bad Food? Who knows. Seems so. 

Bad Experience? Yeah.

Maybe just a bad night for them? Possibly. 


Will I be going back? No. Never. Too much stacked against it at this point.


I am not one of these Yelpers who gets off on disparaging an up and coming small restaurant with a gleefully negative review. I was pulling for them, even despite the service issues, right up until the point 2 gates of hell spawned at each end of my body. It was at that point I figured I should write a review...
author: B S.

description: On a diet and have no budget? This place is for you. Overpriced and lacks sufficient meat proportions in their tacos and burritos. I've eaten here a couple of times because of the convenience but  is mediocre and overpriced for what you are getting. Highly recommend the corn which was very delicious but is $7 dollars. Meat to beans and rice ratio in the burrito is horrible considering how much you are paying. I will definitely commit to driving further into the mission for more meat in my burrito!. The shrimp taco has 3 shrimps and is about $4.50. One sliver of fried fish in the fish taco. $17 dollar dinner consists of one corn, two skinny tacos. I'm a small Asian woman but I had to eat a second dinner.
author: Trini P.

description: A bit surprised by the over-the-top reviews for this spot. I was unimpressed with each part of the meal. I enjoyed the atmosphere and the service was adequate. Drinks were subpar and at $7 for a drink made from a can of Tecate, overpriced. We had the Ceviche, a couple tacos (tiny for $4.50 each) and duck quesadilla. It left me wishing I made dinner at home. The regulars seemed to love it cause they were waiting for a seat...they can have mine.
author: Nate B.

description:
Papito has a GREAT burrito ;) amazing guacamole ,incredible white sangria and a french speaking staff.
Not sure if i have left anything out but i am coming back!!!!
Cheers;)
author: Yulenka M.

description:
The food here is excellent! I believe we have gotten lucky both times we've dined at Papito in that they clearly have limited seating and we happened to arrive before the dinner rush. I don't think I would try and go here after 7 pm (either that or go for a very late dinner).

We tried the Mole Enchiladas, which we requsted to be made vegetarian due to a friend's dietary restriction, and I expected them to supplement the meatless version with tofu. Instead, the filling was composed of fresh, grilled vegetables and it was extremely tasty. I loved it!

I have also tried the fish tacos, the duck confit tacos, and the churro dessert. Everything is delicious.
author: Morris H.

description: Best tacos I've ever had, including the tacos I've had in Mexico. The duck confit is sensational and truly lives up to the hype. Great service, atmosphere and food makes Papito my fave Mexican bistro of all time!
author: Loretta G.

description:
I was seeing if this should get 4 stars, because 'as good as it gets' is a bold statement.  Then thinking about what this place actually is, hands down 5 stars.  It's a casual Mexican eatery, with everything done better than most places in town.  The owner/manager(?) has a gnarly voice like he should be singing in a metal band.  They have elote, but the mainstays are the tacos, and burritos.  

Probably the best sangria's I've EVER had hands down.  Both the red and white (nice and sweet, almost like a syrup) are fantastic.  The other phenom item are the tempura shrimp tacos...they are simply amazing.   The sidekick gets a vege quesadilla, and it's super good the way they cook the mushrooms...they even threw in some tofu.  I think in general what makes this place good is the fresh authentic taste to all their dishes, and the flavors just pop.  Simple items like good cheese and prep can make any dish good, and they take the time to do it.  I can't explain the flavors you get at some Mexican places where the tortillas and cheeses and sauces just taste right, but this place does it.   Gets packed on a weekend night, but I love that I have a local that is this good!

The brunch is sub-par, so don't bother.  I simply can't find a burrito that compares in town (fried shrimp is insanely good).
author: A A.

description: very cute place.  We ordered the corn to start, very yummy.  We also got the steak tacos and the grilled chicken cilantro salad which was very fresh and tasty.
author: Wen B.

description:
I tried Papito for the first time today and it was delicious. Judging by the constant stream of patrons (and yes, they do carry out service as well), I am not the only one who enjoys this Potrero Hill gem.

I sat outside for lunch and enjoyed a shrimp taco and a chicken taco.  Both tacos were awesome.  The flavors were bright and fresh.  

I'll be back!
author: April W.

description: My friends and I had a great experience here. Our waiter was very accommodating and the rest of the staff was lively. The fried shrimp super burrito hit the spot. Chips come with a few unique sauces. Very decent prices. Good time overall.
author: Sylvester N.

description:
This food is seriously nothing short of absolutely delicious.

Originally, I popped in here with the man and just wanted a quick bite.  We weren't sure where to go, but I remembered I'd wanted to try Papito.  So, we ponied up to the bar and decided to stay mostly from the welcoming words from the bartender/waiter/proprietor.

I love chorizo and they have a very cool burger that's part Mexican sausage.  They also have amazing quesadillas.  In fact, we went again last night and I had the fried chicken one.  As described by the waiter and confirmed by  my mouth, "it is killer."

That said, if you've not tried this place, check it out.  It's well worth the money and a local gem indeed.  I'll be there much more often!
author: Andy S.

description:
argh, should i write this review and have more people potential come raid our few awesome places on the hill? fine!!!!!

ill keep it short and sweet.  after they got tired of pizza nostra they opened this place and like their other restaurants, they've done an amazing job.  thanks for bringing another great restaurant close to home! :)
author: Melody T.

description:
I went there after seeing 4 star ratings on yelp. Honestly, the place deserves full five stars.

The food was delicious, the service prompt and prices reasonable. I ordered two tacos and a super burrito for myself. The host was quick to point out that either one of them would be enough for one person. I went with the burrito. It was excellent to say the least.

The ambience of the place gave it a really cool neighborhood restaurant feel. I strongly recommend any one living in this area to check this place out.
author: Abhinai S.

description: Interesting twist of French-Mexican fusion with choices like duck confit tacos.  But to be honest nothing extraordinarily spectacular about the food and the prices are a bit steep. Also the burritos are loose and more difficult to eat as they fall apart.  Interesting to try but somewhere you become a regular.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Ahhhh - yet another disappointing restaurant in Portrero Hill. I had very high hopes for this place. Who doesn't want a chic/tasty go-to Mexican restaurant where you can dine or dash?! 

Well, shortly after it opened my husband and I went to give it a go. First I was offered sour white wine (the server even admitted it was old!) that tasted horrible. I was quick to judge but instead labeled him as lazy since (he had to run to their sister restaurant to pick-up some additional bottles). 

We ordered the soup - which wasn't bad but wasn't amazing. I ordered the tofu tacos and my husband ordered a burrito. I was SO pissed when my street tacos came and there were MAYBE two of the smallest pieces of tofu I've ever seen in both. Not only that. but the tofu was prepared horribly and was a bit chewy and tasteless - well, hard to taste being that they were so small. I was confused why they'd even offer a tofu taco if that was how they'd serve it. It tasted and looked like a lame attempt to appease vegetarians - they failed! 

Additionally, the tacos had hardly anything on them - I basically ate a small corn tortilla with cabbage and sauce. I was so upset that our bill was comparable to a nice restaurant that I vowed never to dine there again OR recommend it. 

Now, my husband's burrito got quite a bit attention - and not in a good way. He chowed it down but agreed the quality wasn't worth the $13 bucks or whatever. He had a nice little reminder early the next morning when he sat on the porcelain throne revisiting the memory of his meal from the night before. 

Gross right?! Well, clearly the food is to!

I'm so sad that Potrero doesn't have better places to eat. The staples that have been there are fabulous - but these newbie's act like the hood doesn't know shit from good.
author: Tarah B.

description: My daughter and I went there in late April And experienced great food and friendly service.  I would call their fair Mexican Cosmopolitan/metro Food.  The shrimp tacos were exceptional. My five-day visit I there twice.  Indianapolis we need a Papito's or something like it.
author: Chip R.

description:
Very impressed with the food here! I've been twice in the last week!

First visit: started with the heirloom and nopales salad - mind blowing! Every ingredient stood on its own and was delicious, but together, they were even better. The cilantro pistou that was drizzled on top really pulled it all together... I'll be back for this dish! Also had the duck carnitas taco and the Papito's taco. The duck was AH-MAZ-INGLY tasty, excellent with the addition of the mild salsa verde and the medium mango salsa. The Papito's taco was ok, original for sure, and tasty, but nothing I would order again. 

The second visit: started with the enmolada and the ceviche. The enmolada was good, not the best I've tried, but it was certainly tasty. The ceviche was decent but difficult to eat... it's served with chips that weren't anything special. Probably will not get re-ordered, but I'm glad I tried it! I had the duck carnitas (again) and this time tried the Baja Taco - probably the best fish taco I've tried in SF proper. I will come back for this! 

The tacos are gigantic, I could barely eat two! Boyfriend had the burrito, said it was a pretty typical burrito. I highly recommend the tacos!

The servers here are excellent and very friendly as well! Thanks, Papito!
author: Aryn Y.

description:
I just ate here as a last minute choice since Sunflower was closed for some odd reason at 3pm. But i guess that's normal in potrero hill. Anyways, Papito was not a bad choice. The place is small but that attribute translates into quick and very personal service. 

I was in health-mode mood so i decided on two of their entrées: the guacamole and the shrimp  ceviche. The order came with chips and three style of salsas, which i thought were very good. However, I think they would've been complimented far better with small warm corn tortillas.  The Guacamole was very good and it comes with huge chunks of avocado in it - enough to heavily consider it a meal. 

The ceviche, or to me, the main dish, comes with prawn-sized shrimp, mangoes, onions and some other good stuff. Which brings me down to the 3-stars. Although this is probably my own fault - everything was excellent, the ceviche was just plainly too salty. The saltiness was enhanced by the corn chips which were also salty. Perhaps if i would've ordered something else to offset the saltiness, I would've had a better experience. But salt with salt always equals too much salt. I also believe ceviche should be marinated and cooked with lime. This is probably how this was made, but the yummy lime flavors you come to expect from ceviche were nowhere to be found, which was a bummer. I think my expectations of ceviche are way high here, so i apologize for being bias about the taste.

On another positive note, the bathroom was very clean. In my opinion, the bathroom experience always extends to the kitchen and the overall cleanliness of the establishment. :) 

Besides the mediocre ceviche experience, I will definitely be coming back to try their many other dishes.
author: Rob M.

description:
Went here when it first opened and had the shrimp taco's and chorizo tacos which were superb. On my recent visit wanted to try something diffrent and went with a super burrito with steak, I was very disappointed with this it was very plain did not have much of a taste. The black beans were very good inside but the meat and rice seemed like it was lacking something.

If you go here stick to the tacos! :)
author: Michael W.

description:
Terrible customer service!

I used to frequent this restaurant because I live in the neighborhood and I have a sweet spot for it. One of my first dates with my boyfriend of several years was here and we had a great time. It was on a slower night and the gentleman working was very attentive and charming. 

The bad review is because the last several times we have tried to eat here have been a customer service disaster. About one month ago we called for Carry-out because the food is good, but the service had been lacking and it can be a long wait since it is so small. The answering machine picked up and literally says "We are too busy to talk to you." That was very off-putting so we ate somewhere else. You'd think at a small restaurant that they would be eager to do carry-out orders because they still make the money, while not having to have space for you. 

Last week we tried to go eat there and put our name on the list and waited outside. Another couple showed up and took a table outside. Three tables outside were open. At this point there was no one else waiting for a table and we didn't want to eat outside because it was chilly. The manager (the French guy) came out and rudely told them to stand up and wait for their turn. He told them to put their name on the list. They looked very confused and annoyed. No one else was waiting. They put their name on the list, then he sat them back down at the table and crossed their name off. They looked like they were about to get up and leave because of how ridiculous that was, but ended up staying and ordering. I understand and appreciate first come, first serve, but there was only our name on the list so far and three open tables...If we wanted to sit outside we would have and a list wouldn't have existed yet.

A few more people came and added their name to the list under ours. Some bar seats opened up. About ten minuetes went by and no one came out to seat the empty space, so my boyfriend and I wiped our name off the list and sat down. The manager (who had seen us waiting outside and knew our name was at the top of the list becuase of the outdoor seating fiasco) rudely told us to wait outside because there was a list. We explained that we were at the top of the list. The manager rolled his eyes and went outside and said our name wasn't on the list. The peole outside said we were first. The manager made a snide remark about us lying about having had our name on the list. So, we left. That was the last straw for us. On the way out the manager grabbed my boyfriend's arm and tried to make us stay in a desperate attempt, because he knew he was in the wrong. We left and ate at Goat Hill. Never going to Papitos again.

It's so sad. The food is good. The customer service is getting worse and worse.
author: SF R.

description:
Service friendlier this time. But what moves me to write this review is the food.

Okay, have to raise it to five stars. Quality not quantity, but that mahi mahi over poblano rice was just so perfectly done with only the lightest of grill marks (I get so tired of burnt food, so this was very welcome) and so flavorful I just couldn't help myself and had to follow each bite with another bite. Yum!

And the flan was wonderful, with the caramelizing stopping, once again, short of burnt, and a few raspberries on top.

I need to make the shlep to Potrero more often.
author: Charles B.

description:
Papito is part of Potrero Hill's microcosm of gourmet. As such, it shares a number of characteristics with some of its neighbors: smaller portions, cramped setting, higher prices. But, you'll also get some friendly service and some delicious bites that will challenge and enthrall you.

Papito does Mexican, from standard (including tacos, burritos, quesadillas) to some more exotic tapas, including queso fundito, a delicious baked cheese and chile dish, shrimp ceviche, roasted corn with cheese, black beans with or without beef chorizo, etc. 

We had those tapas last night, which were all reminiscent of homey peasant-style food one might expect in Oaxaca, but at San Francisco prices. However, since we don't know any Oaxacan peasants, we'll be continuing to go to Papito for this kind of delicious chow. Also, they're open late!
author: Tom S.

description: I can't speak for the food because I did not eat any. I have heard very good things. Unfortunately I was not able to eat anything. I have a good allergy to onions. When I eat them I get really sick, not dying sick but miserable sick. I scoured the menu for options with no onions. When I found one that looked promising I asked the waiter if it had onions. He said no. I then asked him if the salsa in the dish had onions. He said he didn't think so but he would check. He came back and let me know that the salsa had onions but he could take it out. In the meantime we ordered some guacamole (no onions mentioned on the menu) it arrived and was full of onions with onions on top as a garnish. I just waited for my meal and let my date eat the guacamole. When my food arrived it had a pile of fresh cut onions on top. From the side I could see that I was also full of onions. I asked the server if he could alert my waiter. When the waiter (a different one) arrived I told him that I was allergic to onions and could not eat the dish. He told my server to just take them off the top. I told him that would not work and that the dish was also full of onions. He was then extremely rude asking me me what I wanted and that it was a Mexican restaurant so of course onions are in everything. He told me to order something else from the menu but I asked him if he could tell me what did not have onions. He pointed out a number of dishes with onions on the description. I pointed that out to him and he basically yelled at me that he could take them out. I said no thank you and that we would just take the check. My date asked for a box (and here is the worst part!) the waiter yelled at the server to get us a box "vamonos!" he said and clapped at the server (who was a Spanish speaker and extremely nice). In the end we were not charged for any food which was nice and why I gave any stars at all. In future I recommend listening to your customers, if you can not provide what they area asking for, say so. Don't yell at them or make them feel bad and DO NOT disrespect your staff!!
author: Momo A.

description:
The tacos are really good and I found inexpensive for the quality and creativity.
My only con is that the place is small and crowded.

Ceviche: Perfect.  Fresh, spicy and delicious
Pastor Taco:  Yum.  The roasted pineapple was super yummy.
Camaron Costeño:  Yum.

I can't wait to go back and try the other tacos, as well as, the quesadillas look good.
author: Valerie D.

description: Decided on Papitos because we heard they served queso fundido, and we haven't been able to find it in SF, yet. It was a Saturday afternoon, so they were offering their brunch menu....but they were nice enough to make us the queso even though it wasn't on the brunch menu. We were very appreciative of them accommodating our request. They also brought my dog a bowl of water without me even having to ask. The guacamole was nice and fresh, along with the chips and complimentary trio of salsas. I ordered fried chicken quesadillas and my hubby tried the fish burrito. I think this is the first time I've seen fried chicken as an option for tacos or quesadillas. The quesadillas weren't my fave...they were filled with a little too much spicy sauce, and usually love spicy foods. That's okay though. My hubby really enjoyed the fish burrito. Maybe I'll try that next time. Aside from the friendly service, we really liked the location. It's nothing fancy, but we never realized Potrero Hill was a fun spot to "hit up." There are actually a bunch of restaurants right around Papitos.
author: Kelsey K.

description: Came here on Valentines day and was not disappointed at all. When I think Mexican food, I think heavy and fattening, but this place challenged that stereotype, because we left feeling satisfied enough to where we were full but not in a negative "want to sleep" way. For our starter we had Corn that was DELICIOUS! I don't know how they seemed to make eating corn on the cob fancy but they nailed it. For dinner i had the chicken burrito and a bit of my friends shrimp taco, both which were mouth watering. The mango sauce with my burrito paired very well and it was decent sized and filling. I defiantly will be coming back when I am in the area to try there other items. It's really hard to find a place where the service is good, the food is clean, not heavy but filling and this place is one of them!
author: Sara A.

description: Stay away from this place. The first time I went there I had the chicken soup which I felt like could have been good except the zucchini was so bitter and the chicken was so dry, I couldn't eat it. I then tried to give the place a second chance today and had a salad. Once again, I was served food that was terrible. The lettuce was brown, wilted and disgusting. I told the server and he did absolutely nothing except tell me that he wasn't the manager. Bottom line, gross food and bad service. I definitely won't be back.
author: K. N.

description:
I may not be a professional Burrito eater but I have had quite a few all around town and I think this is the best one I've had in SF. 

The Burrito mojado is spectacular. The service was a little iffy but the food definitely made up for it. Oh yeah, don't get the Raspberry Margarita.
author: Eric G.

description:
WOW!  Who knew the french could cook mexican food!  I love their tacos.  I've had their elote, camaron(shrimp) costeno taco, carnitas de pato(duck) taco and baja taco(rock cod).  

Two tacos is more than enough food.  Each taco comes with two tortillas and you can make two tacos out of one since they give you a hearty portion.  The food tastes so fresh and savory you'll be coming back again and again.  I was really disappointed by my elote.  I don't mind spending $5 for mexican corn but it has to be good.

5 stars for the tacos and 1 star for the elote.

They have a variety of cervesas so this place is great for a hot and cheap night out.
author: Eleanor L.

description:
i went with some friends last night for the first time.
the verdict is definitely 5 stars for the food
ceviche, duck burrito, fried chicken quesadilla, mexican flan, all were amazing
good music, good vibe, good service...
author: Jessie B.

description:
Complimentary shots of Tres Agaves in lieu of the traditional after-dinner mint? Yes please.

Oh and the food was amazing too. I had the duck confit quesadilla (which tasted equally as good, if not better, the next day) with a glass of white sangria. Definitely coming back here. Only con was that the inside got pretty hot. Try and snag a patio table if possible.
author: Patrick M.

description: Fresh and delicious. Vegetarian tacos were shockingly good; perfect tortillas, fancy mushrooms, crisp tofu.
author: Loren C.

description:
CUTE CUTE CUTE place!!! We went with a group of 10 and we all crowded around a  table on the slanted sidewalk. Needless to say I sat at the end lower end, so if the food started rolling, I would get it all. Price is sooo cheap for dinner and a number of choices for burritos, quesdillas, and tacos. Service is super fast and a great time all around. I had the carnita quesdilla, which is filled with spicy pork and pineapple pico de gallo. The portions are huge, so I shared it with my boyfriend. 

For dessert we got the churros.... AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS. The freshly fried taste of heaven with the melted bittersweet chocolate is perfect on a chilly night after your meal.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Many people complain that everything at Papito costs a couple bucks more than at your local Mission taqueria, but I think that is fair price to pay for unique meat options and better quality meat.  I mean, you can't get duck confit or tempura shrimp from a traditional Mexican taqueria, and all meats are the same price at Papito so if you want to get more bang for your buck, order a seafood or duck dish!  Also, their prices are slightly different than what is posted online -- yesterday (Saturday) night, it was 2 tacos for $8, a regular burrito for $7, a super burrito for $9, and a quesadilla for $10.  I ordered the duck burrito and it was delicious, the duck just melts in your mouth... mmm...  Moreover, the portions were surprisingly large for a semi-French place -- my regular burrito was about 3/4 the size of a regular Cancun burrito, and was actually even larger than a regular burrito from Pancho Villa.  Oh, and another thing to note -- they serve each table a trio of sauces: spicy, mango, and avocado, and the avocado sauce is delicious!!  And the service is great too!  I asked for some tamarind sauce in my duck burrito (according to the menu it is only served with the duck in quesadilla, not burrito, form), and when the bill arrived I realized they didn't even charge me extra for it!  Lastly, when we were finished, a guy (I'm guessing the owner) came by to ask how we enjoyed our meal.  I will definitely be back!
author: Beatrice W.

description: The fish burrito was the bomb. The fish was breaded and fried to perfection, giving the burrito a bit of a crunchy texture. Pick up extra sauce - portions are big so you'll need it!
author: Eugene B.

description: I love Papito!  The food is very flavorful and it's not super heavy like typical Mexican food.  Plus it's organic!  Usually, I get 2 tacos, which you can mix and match and pick what meat you want.  My favorites are the al pastor, grilled shrimp, and shrimp tempura.  The quesadillas are even better than the tacos, but I usually go for the lighter option.  Guacamole is good.  Their mango salsa adds an extra sweet kick to the food.  Papito is awesome!
author: Y K.

description:
Alright... Papito part duex or dos depending on if you're going off the owners or genre. 

I ordered the duck confit burrito and grilled corn. And was pleasantly surprised with how light the confit actually was. Typically you expect most duck dishes to be quite heavy but the flavors in this burrito were balanced, however, I could have done without the pickled veggies in this dish because of the potential of the vinegar overwhelming the flavor of the duck. The corn was also very nice, great creamy spice flavor from the mexi-mayo. I feel that a lot of new restaus these days are going for smaller portions with bold flavors that aren't gut bombs (eg heavy) and it's particularly true at Papito. Truly great clean food with good flavor, but you leave satiated not full. Service is also quite pleasant. 

My only complaint is price... but I understand, good ingredients cost money. It's just hard to justify on a daily basis. But I can see myself definitely putting Papito on my weekly rotation!
author: Douglas L.

description: For my first time having mexican in almost a year, pretty good!  I had the veggie super burrito and man was it SUPER!  The right amount of black beans, rice, sauces, cheese and veggies! I was really sad that I couldn't finish the entire thing because i had loaded up on chips/salsa/guac too early in the dinner.  Definitely get the guac, it had just the right amount of lime and salt and good texture...nice and chunky.  There were 3 kinds of salsa; I wasn't the biggest fan of the mango because it was a bit too sweet but my friends liked it.  Definitely going back, especially since it's cheap and two blocks away from my sister's house.
author: Kristine N.

description: What a surprise! Cute little space with huge flavor. I had the beef, carnitas and shrimp tacos. I'm still thinking about them. Great service and really flavorful food. I will be going back. I highly recommend this place.
author: Dan D.

description: Really good spot for a locals lunch/dinner. Duck tacos are AMAZING! Service is very good and with personality. Beer and wine list are both adequate and the Michelada is a staple.  Only knock is the lack of space, it fills up quickly.  Overall I would definitely recommend this to anyone in the area.
author: Ramon I.

description: Love this place. Fresh, organic, delicious food. Friendly and charismatic service. Best MexiCal food I have had.
author: Andrew P.

description: Sat down at the little bar and had 3 tacos, Carne asada, pastor and carnitas.  They were all good but I really enjoyed the pastor. It's not a real pastor taco without pineapple and this is one of the few places that makes it the right way. If I was back in the area I would go back for sure.
author: Vince C.

description:
My palate knows about mexican food, my tongue knows about Mexican food, my nose knows about Mexican food, my.... Ok, you get the idea.  Although being Mexican does not mean I know everything about mexican food, I think that at my 48 years of age I should be good at knowing and sometimes crudely comparing taquerias and mexican restaurants around the Bay Area.  
So, last Wednesday around 5:30 pm, I passed by this cute place and I thought, "one more taqueria".  "Papito" as a name seemed absurd to me, but what caught my eye was the word "organic". stopped and read the menu and the "Champiñones quesadilla" called me. 
The place was half empty,  I went in and immediately loved the small but nicely decorated warm place. I sat at the left side of the bar to get a sight of the action in the kitchen.  I got my hot quesadilla and loved the rich flavors of different mashrooms, queso Oaxaca and epazote. The three salsas are very, VERY good! One rule of thumb, my mom would say, is; a place who has good salsas and good spanish rice is worth your money. The price I think was a little on the expensive side, but I thought the food was excellent so let's live it at that.

I told my partner about my new favorite restaurant and next day I passed the word to all my coworkers as well. 
My partner, another more demanding palate than mine, picked me up from work next day and head to Papito around 8:20 pm.  The place was packed but we didn't have to wait long to get sited.  This time I decided to try the "Enmolada' a braised chicken, oaxacan mole, crème fraiche, monterey jack cheese, black beans, spanish rice, pickled red onion platter.  My partner went for the "Champiñones quesadilla".
To my total disappontment, the flavor of the mole was just acceptable, the tortillas were hard to cut and the chiquen was dry and stringy. The rice was also dry and really not exceptional at all... My partner was contempt with his quezadilla, wich I was at least happy to hear.
The three stars I gave might be tough to take, but If your business has a Michelline recomendation, It better step up all the time, when is half empty or completely full.  So for this reason should you come to eat at Papitos only when is half empty? It's your decision.
author: David G.

description:
Definitely good food and good variety. A little pricier than I wanted to spend but I'd be happy to return and recommend it to a friend.

Friendly atmosphere and staff. Quaint, only a handful of tables and some bar seating.

Good size portions.
author: David W.

description:
Yum.
The guacamole is delicious, which in my world is reason enough to go to a place.  I asked for extra chips, and our friendly (albeit frenetic) server obliged quickly and with a smile.
I am a veg, and there was a great selection of vegetarian options, which always makes my day.  In fact, the veg options looked even tastier on the menu than their carne counterparts.
The best part?  Ending my fabulous meal with homemade, creamy and flavorful flan.  Yum, again.  Do yourself and order two, one is not enough to share.  (At least, I did not want to share.)
Be forewarned, this place is small and fills up quickly, but is definitely worth checking out!
author: Lacy T.

description:
When I moved to SF, I heard of a mystical place that distilled duck burritos to the lucky few that found it. 
Since then, this famous burrito has become my favorite, along with their watermelon aqua fresca. 
Love sitting at the bar, their French waitress always has a joke or two while she swiftly runs around. Her music is great too! 
Definitely go.
author: Rajajun S.

description:
Had lunch here today and damn it was good! We shared the duck, carnitas, and papito tacos and the elote and tomate&nopal small dishes and everything was great to amazing. 

Everything was executed amazingly, the staff was incredibly friendly, and we had such a pleasant meal. I am so excited to have the perfect mexican resto on the hill. So excited to be back!

Plus the GM is cuuuuute.
author: Art A.

description: This place is great.! I ordered a carnitas burrito with "the hottest hot sauce you have" - turns out that it is very hot.  Like stomach ache two hours later hot.  But that's how I like it.  Great service, great food, lively staff, cool space, and a good selection of beers.   We ordered tacos, burritos, homemade guac, some negro modelos, and some quesadillas.  Very tasty!  You should go.
author: Joe R.

description:
4.5!!!!!!!!!

oh boy. derishuzness and happyness at thoughts of the meal i've had at this establishment two day ago.

place is small, has a little bar area and some tables that'll fit about 12-14 people. came in at close to 4pm on monday, a couple of guys at the bar nomming, all the tables empty. shweet. my buddy P. and i ordered the fried chicken tacos to share, an order of super burrito with rock cod for me, and the duck confit burrito mojado for him.

for 9 dorraz, we were expecting a good couple of tacos. flavors blended together well enough. the tortillas were solid, they had that healthy, organic taste and a great bite to them. i enjoyed the slaw, and the chicken was tasty enough, but i was not very impressed by the tiny portion (even if i were to have both tacos). also, after having consumed a good amount of chicken and waffles not too long ago, the fried chicken in the tacos here seem to be good, but not crazy amazing at all. don't think i'd order the tacos again, because

the super burrito is where it's at. my rock cod fish super burrito was amazing. flaky fish flesh blended so well with the creaminess of the guac and all the other goodies packed inside. plenty of delicious black beans, and the rice added a great textural contrast. i put on the three different salsas (provided with the complimentary chips at the beginning of the meal) on the burrito before taking a bite - made it even more spectacular.

now, the duck confit burrito mojado. HOLY. so good, so wonderfully duck-gamey. ahhh such a beauty! drenched in all that sauce and cheese, that pungent duck aroma wafting up...got damn. a fantastic contrast with the delicate flavors of the rock cod super burrito. had alternating bites of both types of burritos = party in my moufffff!! they also stuffed the burrito to death with duck. cutting it open, the sight brought happy tears to my eyes.

love how slightly toasty the tortillas were for the burritos :) and the chips given were very moreish too, must be the obvious traces of salt on them - not complaining though. they were good! the entire meal was positively nomzy.
author: Eliza D.

description: Delicious, great service, regular fish burrito (comes with a yummy aioli sauce) and super grilled steak burrito were fresh and tasty.  Paired the steak burrito with their zinfandel...good decision.  Their different salsas and chips were offered immediately as we sat down...yum...we asked for more for our burritos.  Our waiter was friendly and funny.  I paid with a credit card and he called me by my first name when he said goodbye as he saw us walk out.
author: Kumi B.

description: This is a tiny place with quality food and great service at a very affordable price. If you're looking for a burrito the size of your head, you're in the wrong neighborhood.
author: jen h.

description: This place is maddddd good! Jus had the grilled steak super burrito and I gotta say it was one of the better burritos I've had yet.. I wish I was hungrier or had an extra stomach or someshit cos I'd totally eat a couple more burritos. Thanks Papito, you're the man.
author: Don E. D.

description: Finally some Mexican food in Potrero! (Other than Dos Pinas, which is also pretty good) But anyways, we had the ceviche and carnitas quesadilla - both were excellent.  We went on opening night so things were a little crazy, but no complaints here.  Five stars!
author: Cory D.

description: 4.9/5 - Going to have to say this place is almost perfect, and real Elote Asado. A new Potrero favorite... Trio Salsa, Elote (Corn on Cob) OMG! I have to say, this will be a weekly fav for a while.
author: Troy S.

description: Papito's is so good! My favorite is the chicken quesadilla, but I like to get a side of the pineapple pico de gallo since it's also delicious.  The staff here is super friendly and they definitely make this a neighborhood place.  Once they were a little late with the check and brought my friend and I two shots of tequila!  Talk about service!
author: Sarah A.

description: EXCELLENT!! delicious food, wonderful ambiance, and spot on customer service. Its a win win!! Highly recommended.
author: Ahna K.

description: Chicken tacos bomb. com with the habanero house salsa if you can hang!
author: Char Char C.

description: Best fish tacos I've ever had. Great service, nice people.
author: Marcus S.

description:
Love this place.  Paolo is the best.  

Favorites include the fried chicken tacos, the queso fundito, and of course the agave wine margaritas.
author: Jason C.

description:
Food was first rate. Had a small issue when they brought both my wife and my 7 year old's food out with hot sauce on it. Menu did not mention this...and we spoke to our waiter who took it away and replaced it in a jiffy.

Very nice service, food tasted terrific, and my only small complaint was it was a bit pricey for my tacos. $4 bucks a taco...is easily double what the same basic thing costs everywhere else.

In their defense the taco was dolled up nice.
author: bill r.

description:
An excellent place for take-out burritos. First-class ingredients, with a touch of French influence; but it is definitely a Mexican restaurant, rather than some sort of strange fusion. The meat options are all good, as well as the chips and salsa. I have yet to try some of the bigger dishes, but the burritos, tacos, and quesadillas are great.

There are not a lot of seats in the restaurant, so there are usually a few people waiting for a seat outside. However, takeout is always quick and painless.

Probably my favorite Mexican place in the Bay Area.
author: Paul K.

description: I have been coming here since it opened. One of the best Mexican restaurants in SF. It's small, lively, great food and for the most part, has fun fantastic regulars. The entire staff is friendly, welcoming and a pleasure to deal with. Papito is my go to when I want a good meal in a casual setting. I have refrained from yelping about it, as selfishly, I have wanted to keep this place as a little gem of mine. However, when I see people give Papito one star, not only do I question their poor taste, but makes me want to share the real truth. Let's be honest, everybody is entitled to their own opinion/experience, but Papito never fails to deliver pure excellence.
author: Scott G.

description: Our go-to place for some of the most healthful and certainly best tasting Mexican food around here!  Thanks for keeping us going on those long, hard days!
author: Big Daddy's Antiques SF Z.
